Measures.how_calculated: Number of live, singleton births occurring at less than 37 weeks gestation among residents of an area. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live, singleton births occurring at less than 37 weeks gestation among residents of an area, divided by the number of live, singleton births with nonmissing gestational age among residents of the area; expressed as percent. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live, singleton births occurring at less than 32 weeks gestation among residents of an area. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live, singleton births occurring at less than 32 weeks gestation among residents of an area, divided by the number of live, singleton births with nonmissing gestational age among residents of the area; expressed as percent. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live, singleton births with a birthweight less than 1,500 grams (3 lbs 5 oz) among residents of an area. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live, singleton births with a birthweight less than 1,500 grams (3 lbs 5 oz) among residents of an area, divided by the number of live, singleton births with nonmissing birthweight among residents of the area; expressed as percent. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live, singleton, term births with a birthweight less than 2,500 grams (5 lbs, 8 oz) among residents of an area. Term births are those with a gestational age of 37 weeks or more. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live, singleton, term births with a birthweight less than 2,500 grams (5 lbs 8 oz) among residents of an area, divided by the total number of live, singleton, term births with nonmissing birthweight among residents of the area; expressed as percent. All births are restricted to those with a gestational age of 37 weeks or more. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated: Number of deaths occurring at less than 1 year of age. Infant deaths are restricted to those that can be linked to a birth certificate of a NYC resident mother and are mapped to the mother's usual residence at birth. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated: Number of deaths occurring at less than 1 year of age in an area, divided by the number of live births among resident mothers of the area; expressed as cases per 1,000 live births. Infant deaths are restricted to those that can be linked to a birth certificate of a NYC resident mother and are mapped to the mother's usual residence at birth. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated: Number of deaths occurring at less than 28 days of age in an area. For more information about this measure, click here. Neonatal deaths are restricted to those that can be linked to a birth certificate of a NYC resident mother and are mapped to the mother's usual residence at birth.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated: Number of deaths occurring at less than 28 days of age in an area, divided by the number of live births among resident mothers of the area; expressed as cases per 1,000 live births. Neonatal deaths are restricted to those that can be linked to a birth certificate of a NYC resident mother. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated: Number of fetal deaths occurring at 28 or more weeks gestation, plus infant deaths occurring up to 6 days after birth in an area. Deaths are restricted to those that can be linked to a birth certificate of a NYC resident mother and are mapped to the mother's usual residence at birth. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated: Number of fetal deaths occurring at 28 or more weeks gestation, plus infant deaths occurring up to 6 days after birth, divided by the sum of fetal deaths at 28 weeks or more gestation and live births among resident mothers of the area; expressed per 1,000 fetal deaths plus live births. Deaths are restricted to those that can be linked to a birth certificate of a NYC resident mother and are mapped to the mother's usual residence at birth. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics
Measures.DisplayType: per 1,000 live births plus fetal deaths

Measures.how_calculated: Number of deaths occurring from 28 days to less than 1 year of age in an area. Deaths are restricted to those that can be linked to a birth certificate of a NYC resident mother and are mapped to the mother's usual residence at birth. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated: Number of deaths occurring from 28 days to less than 1 year of age in an area, divided by the number of live births among resident mothers of the area; expressed per 1,000 live births. Deaths are restricted to those that can be linked to a birth certificate of a NYC resident mother and are mapped to the mother's usual residence at birth. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated: Sum of annual age-specific birth rates (grouped by 5-year age intervals, from 10 - 49 years) among NYC resident women, multiplied by 5; expressed per 1,000 women. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated: Number of male births divided by the number of female births among resident mothers of the area. Births are restricted to singletons with a gestational age of 37 weeks or more. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of people born outside the US or its territories (which includes Puerto Rico), divided by the total population; expressed as a percent.
Measures.Sources: American Community Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of people born outside the US or its territories  including Puerto Rico.
Measures.Sources: American Community Survey

IndicatorDescription: Occupied housing units with more than one person per room are considered crowded.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of housing units with more than 1 occupant per room, divided by the number of occupied housing units; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: American Community Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of housing units with more than 1 occupant per room.
Measures.Sources: American Community Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Number of housing units built before 1950.
Measures.Sources: United States Census

Measures.how_calculated: Number of housing units built before 1950, divided by all housing units; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: United States Census

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of housing units occupied by the owner, divided by all occupied housing units; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: American Community Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of housing units occupied by the owner.
Measures.Sources: American Community Survey

IndicatorName: Adults with Asthma in the Past 12 Months
IndicatorDescription: Asthma is a common disease characterized by breathing difficulty. Environmental exposures resulting from poor air quality and housing maintenance are known to increase risk of asthma development and trigger asthma symptoms. Beginning in 2017, indicator includes data imputed for missing responses.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults aged 18 years and older who reported medically diagnosed asthma and symptoms in the last 12 months, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults aged 18 years and older who reported medically diagnosed asthma with symptoms in the last 12 months, divided by all adults and adjusted for age; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults aged 18 years and older who reported medically diagnosed asthma with symptoms in the last 12 months, divided by all adults; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorName: Adults Reporting Cockroaches in the Home

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of respondents in an area that reported cockroaches in the past 30 days, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of respondents in an area that reported cockroaches in the past 30 days, divided by the number of respondents in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorName: Adults Reporting Rats or Mice outside Their Building
IndicatorDescription: Mice and rats outside a building can indicate the presence of mice and rats in people's homes - which can trigger asthma and indicate other health-threatening maintenance deficiencies.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults reporting mice or rats outside their building in the past 90 days, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults reporting mice or rats outside their building in the past 90 days, divided by the number of adults in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorName: Adults Reporting Secondhand Smoke at Home
IndicatorDescription: Secondhand smoke, especially indoors, is bad for health - especially for the health of children.

Measures.how_calculated:
Estimated number of adults exposed to second-hand smoke at home, rounded to the nearest 1,000.

 

Adults who are exposed to second-hand smoke all or most of the time in their homes are considered to be exposed to second-hand smoke at home.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated:
Estimated number of adults in an area exposed to second-hand smoke at home, divided by all adults in the area; expressed as percent.

 

Adults who are exposed to second-hand smoke all or most of the time in their homes are considered to be exposed to second-hand smoke at home.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with anencephaly and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with anencephaly and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period, divided by the number of live births over the same period; expressed per 10,000.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with spina bifida (without anencephaly) and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with spina bifida (without anencephaly) and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period, divided by the number of live births over the same period; expressed per 10,000.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with hypoplastic left heart syndrome and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with hypoplastic left heart syndrome and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period, divided by the number of live births over the same period; expressed per 10,000.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with transposition of the great arteries and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with transposition of the great arteries and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period, divided by the number of live births over the same period; expressed per 10,000.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

IndicatorName: Cleft Lip with or without Cleft Palate

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with cleft lip with or without cleft palate and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with cleft lip with or without cleft palate and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period, divided by the number of live births over the same period; expressed per 10,000.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with cleft palate without cleft lip and reported the NYS CMR over the 3 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with cleft palate without cleft lip and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period, divided by the number of live births over the same period; expressed per 10,000.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with hypospadias and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with hypospadias and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period, divided by the number of live births over the same period; expressed per 10,000.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with gastroschisis and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with gastroschisis and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period, divided by the number of live births over the same period; expressed per 10,000.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with upper limb deficiencies and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with upper limb deficiencies and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period, divided by the number of live births over the same period; expressed per 10,000.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with lower limb deficiencies and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with lower limb deficiencies and reported the NYS CMR over the 3 year period, divided by the number of live births over the same period; expressed per 10,000.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with Down Syndrome / Trisomy 21 to women less than 35 years old and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with Down Syndrome / Trisomy 21 to women less than 35 years old and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period, divided by the number of live births over the same period; expressed per 10,000.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

IndicatorName: Down Syndrome / Trisomy 21 (Maternal Age 35 Yrs and Over)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with Down Syndrome / Trisomy 21 to women 35 years or older and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with Down Syndrome / Trisomy 21 to women 35 years or older and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period, divided by the number of live births over the same period; expressed per 10,000.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of carbon monoxide incidents where FDNY measured at least 1 ppm at the scene.
Measures.Sources: Fire Department of New York City (FDNY) Carbon Monoxide Incidents

Measures.how_calculated: Number of carbon monoxide incidents in an area, where FDNY measured at least 1 ppm at the scene, divided by the number of buildings in the area; expressed as incidents per 10,000 buildings.
Measures.Sources: Fire Department of New York City (FDNY) Carbon Monoxide Incidents; New York City Primary Land Use Tax Lot Output (PLUTO™ ) Property Characteristic Data

IndicatorDescription: Cracks or holes are a maintenance deficiency linked to the presence of mice, rats, and cockroaches - which can harm residents' health.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households that reported cracks or holes in the home.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households in an area that reported cracks or holes in the home, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

IndicatorDescription: Older housing and peeling paint can put residents at risk of lead poisoning, due to lead paint - which was banned from household paints in the USA in 1978.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households in an area that were built before 1960 and had peeling paint in areas greater than 8.5" x 11".
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households in an area that were built before 1960 and had peeling paint n areas greater than 8.5" x 11", divided by the total number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

IndicatorDescription: Leaks are a maintenance deficiency that can harm health by introducing mold, which can worsen respiratory conditions like asthma.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households in an area that reported leaks coming from outside the unit, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households in an area that reported leaks coming from outside the unit, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

IndicatorName: Homes with 3 or More Maintenance Deficiencies

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households reporting three or more maintenance deficiencies (heating equipment breakdown, additional heating required, rodent infestation, cracks/holes in the walls, ceilings or floors, broken plaster/peeling paint larger than 8½ x 11 inches, toilet breakdowns, or water leaks from outside the unit).
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households in an area reporting three or more maintenance deficiencies (heating equipment breakdown, additional heating required, rodent infestation, cracks/holes in the walls, ceilings or floors, broken plaster/peeling paint larger than 8½ x 11 inches, toilet breakdowns, or water leaks from outside the unit), divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

IndicatorName: Homes near Structures Rated Good or Excellent
IndicatorDescription: Building quality is a strong predictor of the number of housing maintenance deficiencies in a residence that may contribute to increased risk of acute or chronic health problems.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households that rated their neighborhood structures as good or excellent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households in an area that rated their neighborhood structures as good or excellent, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

IndicatorDescription: The need for supplemental heat may mean a building's main heat source doesn't work - and can indicate the presence of other health-threatening maintenance deficiencies

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households that needed to use a secondary source of heat in addition to their primary source.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households in an area that needed to use a secondary source of heat in addition to their primary source, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

IndicatorName: Homes with Mice or Rats in the Building
IndicatorDescription: The presence of mice or rats in the home is often associated with poor housing maintenance. These pests can contaminate food and contribute to the development and exacerbation of asthma and its symptoms.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households that reported mice or rats in their building in the past 90 days.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households in an area that reported mice or rats in their building in the past 90 days, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

Measures.how_calculated: Ozone concentrations are measured continuously and averaged over each 8-hour period. This measure is the annual number of days with a maximum level above the U.S. standard (0.075 ppm) in the geographic area.
Measures.Sources: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Air Quality System (AQS) Data

Measures.how_calculated: An AQI value of 100 corresponds to the current U.S. standard for ozone (0.075 ppm), and deviations from the standard are expressed as the pollutant concentration divided by the standard and multiplied by 100. Advisory days for sensitive groups are counted when ozone levels are above 100.
Measures.Sources: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA); United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Air Quality System (AQS) Data

Measures.how_calculated: This measure is calculated by averaging PM2.5 levels at each monitor, weighted by the number of samples in each quarter, then taking the weighted average of all monitors in the geographic area.
Measures.Sources: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Air Quality System (AQS) Data

Measures.how_calculated: The 98th percentile 24-hour value, in micrograms per cubic meter. This value is higher than 98 percent of 24-hour values for the year.
Measures.Sources: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Air Quality System (AQS) Data

Measures.how_calculated: Number of days in the year for which values were reported higher than the U.S. standard (35 ug/m3) in the geographic area.
Measures.Sources: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Air Quality System (AQS) Data

Measures.how_calculated: The 98th percentile 24-hour value, in micrograms per cubic meter. This value is higher than 98 percent of 24-hour values for the year.
Measures.Sources: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Air Quality System (AQS) Data

Measures.MeasurementType: Average Annual Number Less Than 50 Yrs Old
Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of female residents, less than 50 yrs old, diagnosed with breast cancer over the 5 year period, divided by 5.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.MeasurementType: Age-Adjusted Rate Less Than 50 Yrs Old
Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of female residents, less than 50 yrs old, diagnosed with breast cancer over the 5 year period, divided by the corresponding age-specific intercensal population estimates (from NYS DOH). The resulting age-specific rates are multiplied by the proportion of the US Census 2000 standard population in each age group. Average age-adjusted rate is the sum of these weighted rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 female residents.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry; United States Census

Measures.MeasurementType: Average Annual Number - 50 Yrs and Older
Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of female residents, 50 yrs and older, diagnosed with breast cancer over the 5 year period, divided by 5.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of female residents, 50 Yrs and Older, diagnosed with breast cancer over the 5 year period, divided by the corresponding age-specific intercensal population estimates (from NYS DOH). The resulting age-specific rates are multiplied by the proportion of the US Census 2000 standard population in each age group. Average age-adjusted rate is the sum of these weighted rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 female residents.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of male residents diagnosed with lung and bronchus cancer over the 5 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of male residents diagnosed with lung and bronchus cancer over the 5 year period, divided by the corresponding age-specific intercensal population estimates (from NYS DOH). The resulting age-specific rates are multiplied by the proportion of the US Census 2000 standard population in each age group. Average age-adjusted rate is the sum of these weighted rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 male residents.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of female residents diagnosed with lung and bronchus cancer over the 5 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of female residents diagnosed with lung and bronchus cancer over the 5 year period, divided by the corresponding age-specific intercensal population estimates (from NYS DOH). The resulting age-specific rates are multiplied by the proportion of the US Census 2000 standard population in each age group. Average age-adjusted rate is the sum of these weighted rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 female residents.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of residents diagnosed with lung and bronchus cancer over the 5 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of residents diagnosed with lung and bronchus cancer over the 5 year period, divided by the corresponding age-specific intercensal population estimates (from NYS DOH). The resulting age-specific rates are multiplied by the proportion of the US Census 2000 standard population in each age group. Average age-adjusted rate is the sum of these weighted rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of male residents diagnosed with pancreatic cancer over the 5 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of male residents diagnosed with pancreatic cancer over the 5 year period, divided by the corresponding age-specific intercensal population estimates (from NYS DOH). The resulting age-specific rates are multiplied by the proportion of the US Census 2000 standard population in each age group. Average age-adjusted rate is the sum of these weighted rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 male residents.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of female residents diagnosed with pancreatic cancer over the 5 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of female residents diagnosed with pancreatic cancer over the 5 year period, divided by the corresponding age-specific intercensal population estimates (from NYS DOH). The resulting age-specific rates are multiplied by the proportion of the US Census 2000 standard population in each age group. Average age-adjusted rate is the sum of these weighted rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 female residents.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of residents diagnosed with pancreatic cancer over the 5 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of residents diagnosed with pancreatic cancer over the 5 year period, divided by the corresponding age-specific intercensal population estimates (from NYS DOH). The resulting age-specific rates are multiplied by the proportion of the US Census 2000 standard population in each age group. Average age-adjusted rate is the sum of these weighted rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

The resulting age-specific rates are multiplied by the proportion of the US Census 2000 standard population in each age group. Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of female residents diagnosed with brain and other nervous system cancer over the 5 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of female residents diagnosed with brain and other nervous system cancer over the 5 year period, divided by the corresponding age-specific intercensal population estimates (from NYS DOH). The resulting age-specific rates are multiplied by the proportion of the US Census 2000 standard population in each age group. Average age-adjusted rate is the sum of these weighted rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 female residents.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of residents diagnosed with brain and other nervous system cancer over the 5 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of residents diagnosed with brain and other nervous system cancer over the 5 year period, divided by the corresponding age-specific intercensal population estimates (from NYS DOH). The resulting age-specific rates are multiplied by the proportion of the US Census 2000 standard population in each age group. Average age-adjusted rate is the sum of these weighted rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of male residents diagnosed with non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma over the 5 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of female residents diagnosed with non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma over the 5 year period, divided by the corresponding age-specific intercensal population estimates (from NYS DOH). The resulting age-specific rates are multiplied by the proportion of the US Census 2000 standard population in each age group. Average age-adjusted rate is the sum of these weighted rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 female residents.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of female residents diagnosed with non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma over the 5 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of male residents diagnosed with non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma over the 5 year period, divided by the corresponding age-specific intercensal population estimates (from NYS DOH). The resulting age-specific rates are multiplied by the proportion of the US Census 2000 standard population in each age group. Average age-adjusted rate is the sum of these weighted rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 male residents.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

IndicatorDescription: Asthma hospitalizations are more severe asthma outcomes. They're often clustered in high-poverty neighborhoods, where disinvestment and poor housing conditions expose residents to triggers.

Measures.how_calculated:
Number of asthma-related hospitalizations among NYC resident children up to 4 years old.

 

A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Measures.how_calculated:
Number of asthma-related hospitalizations among NYC resident children up to 4 years old, divided by the population of children up to 4 years old, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents.

 

A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

IndicatorDescription: Heart attacks can stem from genetic, lifestyle, and environmental factors including ambient air pollution and second-hand smoke.

Measures.how_calculated:
Number of NYC resident adults 35 to 64 years hospitalized for heart attack (acute myocardial infarction).

 

A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 410 or an ICD-10 rincipal diagnosis code of I21 or I22 and excluded if the patient was transfered from one urgrent care facility within NYC to another.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Measures.how_calculated:
Number of NYC resident adults 35 to 64 years hospitalized for heart attack (acute myocardial infarction) divided by the population 65 years and older; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates. 

 

A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 410 or an ICD-10 rincipal diagnosis code of I21 or I22 and excluded if the patient was transfered from one urgrent care facility within NYC to another.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Measures.MeasurementType: Age-Adjusted Rate - Adults 35 to 64 Yrs Old
Measures.how_calculated:
Number of NYC resident adults 35 to 64 years old hospitalized for heart attack (acute myocardial infarction), summed within 5-year age groups, and divided by the population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents.

 

A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 410 or an ICD-10 rincipal diagnosis code of I21 or I22 and excluded if the patient was transfered from one urgrent care facility within NYC to another.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Measures.how_calculated:
Number of NYC resident adults 65 years and older hospitalized for heart attack (acute myocardial infarction). 

 

A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 410 or an ICD-10 rincipal diagnosis code of I21 or I22 and excluded if the patient was transfered from one urgrent care facility within NYC to another.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Measures.how_calculated:
Number of NYC resident adults 65 years and older hospitalized for heart attack (acute myocardial infarction) divided by the population 65 years and older; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates. 

 

A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 410 or an ICD-10 rincipal diagnosis code of I21 or I22 and excluded if the patient was transfered from one urgrent care facility within NYC to another.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Measures.MeasurementType: Age-Adjusted Rate Adults - 65 Yrs and Older
Measures.how_calculated:
Number of NYC resident adults 65 years and older hospitalized for heart attack (acute myocardial infarction), summed within 5-year age groups, and divided by the population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents. 

 

A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 410 or an ICD-10 rincipal diagnosis code of I21 or I22 and excluded if the patient was transfered from one urgrent care facility within NYC to another.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households that reported regular exterminator service.

Measures.how_calculated: An AQI value of 100 corresponds to the current U.S. standard for a pollutant (0.075 ppm for ozone, 35 ug/m3 for PM2.5), and deviations from the standard are expressed as the pollutant concentration divided by the standard and multiplied by 100. Advisory days for the general public are counted when either ozone or PM2.5 levels are above 150.
Measures.Sources: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Air Quality System (AQS) Data

Measures.how_calculated: An AQI value of 100 corresponds to the current U.S. standard for a pollutant (0.075 ppm for ozone, 35 ug/m3 for PM2.5), and deviations from the standard are expressed as the pollutant concentration divided by the standard and multiplied by 100. Advisory days for sensitive groups are counted when either ozone or PM2.5 levels are above 100.
Measures.Sources: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Air Quality System (AQS) Data

Excludes products classified as disinfectant, sanitizer, microbicide, microbicide/microbistat, insect growth regulator, insecticide, miticide, or termiticide.

Measures.how_calculated: Sum of pounds of solid pesticide applications that meet the following qualifications: classified as insect growth regulator, insecticide, miticide, or termiticide; having the term bait or gel in the product name, or containing active ingredients boric acid, disodium octaborate tetrahydrate, sodium tetraborate (pentahydrate), indoxacarb, silica gel, diatomaceous earth, (Z)-9-tricosene, S-methoprene, spinosad, hydramethylnon, pyriproxyfen, or fipronil; and not containing active ingredients of the chemical classes pyrethrins, pyrethroids, N-methyl carbamates or organophosphorous compounds.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with Tetralogy of Fallot and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with Tetralogy of Fallot and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period, divided by the number of live births over the same period; expressed per 10,000.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Sum of pounds of solid pesticide applications that are classified as rodenticide.

Measures.how_calculated: The NYC Department of Transportation (DOT) has under its purview 842 bridges. Federal and State law require that bridges be inspected a minimum of every two years. New York State performs the actual bridge inspections and assigns a numerical rating. The NYC DOT then translates those ratings to the verbal designations of "very good," "good," "fair" or "poor." This indicator is the percent of bridges rated as either "very good", "good", or "fair".
Measures.Sources: New York City Mayor's Office of Long Term Planning and Sustainability (OLTPS) PlaNYC Indicator Data

Measures.how_calculated: The NYC DOT Street Assessment Unit conducts an annual pavement condition survey that assesses conditions for one half of New York City streets. The entire city is evaluated once every two years. Street Assessment inspectors rate individual city streets on a scale of 1 through 10 (1 being the worst and 10 being the best). Any street that receives a rating of 7 or below is eligible for resurfacing, whereas any street with a rating of 8 through 10 is not eligible and is in a state of good repair. Reported are the percentages of streets rating between 8 and 10.
Measures.Sources: New York City Mayor's Office of Long Term Planning and Sustainability (OLTPS) PlaNYC Indicator Data

Measures.how_calculated: The number of subway stations for which infrastructure components are replaced on a schedule consistent with its life expectancy. The indicator tracks how many stations have been renovated by the end of their expected useful life, expressed as a percentage.
Measures.Sources: Metropolitan Transportation Authority

Measures.how_calculated: The percentage of the census block area that falls within 1/4 mile of a park edge in a given year, multiplied by the total population of the Census block, summed for all census blocks, then expressed as a percent of 2000 Census population.
Measures.Sources: New York City Department of Parks and Recreation

Measures.how_calculated:
The number of metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalent (CO2e) emitted by NYC buildings (direct emissions from combustion of fuel oil and natural gas, indirect emissions from generation of electricity and steam); transportation (direct emissions from buses, commuter rail, trucks, and passenger cars, and indirect emissions from electricity for mass transit); and indirect emissions from generation of electricity used in streetlights and traffic signals; together with fugitive and process emissions (from solid waste management, electricity distribution, wastewater treatment, and vehicle cooling). CO2 equivalent includes emissions of CO2 as well as an equivalent amount of CO2 (in terms of global warming impact) of other greenhouse gases, including methane, nitrous oxide, hydroflourocarbons, perfluorocarbons, and sulfur hexafluoride. Each gas is converted to CO2e, based on its potential to trap heat in the Earth's atmosphere, and emissions from all six gases are added together for reporting in one common unit.
The total is divided by the NYC intercensal population estimates, which are calculated by the US Census Bureau and then verified by the NYC Department of City Planning.
Measures.Sources: New York City Mayor's Office of Long Term Planning and Sustainability (OLTPS) PlaNYC Indicator Data

Measures.how_calculated:
The number of metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalent (CO2e) emitted by NYC buildings (direct emissions from combustion of fuel oil and natural gas, indirect emissions from generation of electricity and steam); transportation (direct emissions from buses, commuter rail, trucks, and passenger cars, and indirect emissions from electricity for mass transit); and indirect emissions from generation of electricity used in streetlights and traffic signals; together with fugitive and process emissions (from solid waste management, electricity distribution, wastewater treatment, and vehicle cooling). CO2 equivalent includes emissions of CO2 as well as an equivalent amount of CO2 (in terms of global warming impact) of other greenhouse gases, including methane, nitrous oxide, hydroflourocarbons, perfluorocarbons, and sulfur hexafluoride. Each gas is converted to CO2e, based on its potential to trap heat in the Earth's atmosphere, and emissions from all six gases are added together for reporting in one common unit.
The total is divided by the gross city product (GCP); expressed in millions of 2005 dollars.
Measures.Sources: New York City Mayor's Office of Long Term Planning and Sustainability (OLTPS) PlaNYC Indicator Data

Measures.how_calculated: The number of metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalent (CO2e) emitted by NYC buildings (direct emissions from combustion of fuel oil and natural gas, indirect emissions from generation of electricity and steam); transportation (direct emissions from buses, commuter rail, trucks, and passenger cars, and indirect emissions from electricity for mass transit); and indirect emissions from generation of electricity used in streetlights and traffic signals; together with fugitive and process emissions (from solid waste management, electricity distribution, wastewater treatment, and vehicle cooling). CO2 equivalent includes emissions of CO2 as well as an equivalent amount of CO2 (in terms of global warming impact) of other greenhouse gases, including methane, nitrous oxide, hydroflourocarbons, perfluorocarbons, and sulfur hexafluoride. Each gas is converted to CO2e, based on its potential to trap heat in the Earth's atmosphere, and emissions from all six gases are added together for reporting in one common unit.
Measures.Sources: New York City Mayor's Office of Long Term Planning and Sustainability (OLTPS) PlaNYC Indicator Data

Measures.how_calculated:
The number of metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalent (CO2e) emitted by NYC buildings (direct emissions from combustion of fuel oil and natural gas, indirect emissions from generation of electricity and steam); transportation (direct emissions from buses, commuter rail, trucks, and passenger cars, and indirect emissions from electricity for mass transit); and indirect emissions from generation of electricity used in streetlights and traffic signals; together with fugitive and process emissions (from solid waste management, electricity distribution, wastewater treatment, and vehicle cooling). CO2 equivalent includes emissions of CO2 as well as an equivalent amount of CO2 (in terms of global warming impact) of other greenhouse gases, including methane, nitrous oxide, hydroflourocarbons, perfluorocarbons, and sulfur hexafluoride. Each gas is converted to CO2e, based on its potential to trap heat in the Earth's atmosphere, and emissions from all six gases are added together for reporting in one common unit.
The number for each year is expressed as a percentage of 2005 base output. When the city has met its goal of a 30% reduction, this indicator will read "70".
Measures.Sources: New York City Mayor's Office of Long Term Planning and Sustainability (OLTPS) PlaNYC Indicator Data

Measures.MeasurementType: Average Daily Water Use per Capita
Measures.how_calculated: The average daily number of gallons of drinking water diverted to in-city supply over the course of the year. This amount is divided by the NYC intercensal population estimates, which are calculated by the US Census Bureau and then verified by the NYC Department of City Planning.
Measures.Sources: New York City Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) Drinking Water Supply and Quality Report

Measures.MeasurementType: Cumulative Number of New Units since 2007
Measures.how_calculated: The cumulative sum of the number of Certificates of Occupancy, including Temporary Certificates of Occupancy, issued annually by the Department of Buildings since the inception of PlaNYC in 2007. A Certificate of Occupancy is required by the City and indicates that a building is ready for occupation.
Measures.Sources: New York City Department of City Planning (DCP) Permit and Occupancy Data

Measures.how_calculated: The number of housing units in NYC is derived from the Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS), which is a triennial, population-based, cross-sectional survey of housing units in NYC.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

Measures.MeasurementType: Housing Affordable for Median Income NYC Household
Measures.how_calculated: For each year of Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS) data, a housing budget is calculated by taking the estimated citywide median household income for all households (from the HVS), divided by 12 months, and multiplied by 0.3. The estimated percentage of rental units (occupied and vacant/available for rent) with an asking rent (contract) less than or equal to the derived maximum housing budget are counted as affordable to the typical NYC household. This measure incorporates changes in median household income as well as changes in asking rent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated citywide number of vacant or available for rent units in the lowest rent category (<$700 real 2008 dollars), divided by the citywide estimate of total rental units (occupied and available for rent) in that category.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

Measures.MeasurementType: New Permits for Units within 1/2 Mile of Transit
Measures.how_calculated: The percentage of new building permits for residential units issued annually by the Department of Buildings that are located within a 1/2 mile radius of a transit node (e.g., subway stop, commuter rail station).
Measures.Sources: New York City Department of City Planning (DCP) Permit and Occupancy Data

Measures.how_calculated: The amount of fuel oil, electricity, natural gas, and steam power used in the City's residential building stock is converted to MMBTU and then divided by the City population. Because a hotter or colder summer or winter can have a significant impact on energy usage, this metric lessens the effects of weather by calculating a 3 year rolling average of energy usage for each year.
Measures.Sources: New York City Mayor's Office of Long Term Planning and Sustainability (OLTPS) PlaNYC Indicator Data

Measures.how_calculated: The number of pounds of CO2e produced by all NYC sources of electricity, divided by the citywide electric energy usage in megawatt-hours. The amount of CO2e that an electricity source will produce depends on the fuel that is burned and loss that occurs within the distribution network. CO2 equivalents include both emissions of CO2 as well as an equivalent amount of CO2 (in terms of global warming impact) of greenhouse gases of other greenhouse gases. These gases include methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs) and sulfur hexafluoride (SF6), each of which has a specific global warming potential (potential to trap heat in Earth's atmosphere). All six greenhouse gases are converted to CO2e and added together to report in one common unit.
Measures.Sources: New York City Mayor's Office of Long Term Planning and Sustainability (OLTPS) PlaNYC Indicator Data

Measures.how_calculated: ConEdison calculates a System Average Interruption Frequency Index (SAIFI) on an annual basis, which gauges the relative reliability of the NYC electricity network. It does so by measuring the average number of service interruptions per 1000 customers in a given year.
Measures.Sources: New York City Mayor's Office of Long Term Planning and Sustainability (OLTPS) PlaNYC Indicator Data

Measures.how_calculated: The amount of fuel oil, electricity, natural gas, and steam power used in the City's building stock is converted to MMBTU and then divided by the City population. Because a hotter or colder summer or winter can have a significant impact on energy usage, this metric lessens the effects of weather by calculating a 3 year rolling average of energy usage for each year.
Measures.Sources: New York City Mayor's Office of Long Term Planning and Sustainability (OLTPS) PlaNYC Indicator Data

Measures.how_calculated: The annual average dissolved oxygen concentration (mg/L) across Harbor Survey stations. There is a NYS standard of 5.0mg/L necessary to allow bathing, in addition to a less stringent standard to allow fishing and boating. A higher number indicates a cleaner harbor.
Measures.Sources: New York Harbor Water Quality Survey

Measures.how_calculated: The annual geometric mean of fecal coliform counts across Harbor Survey stations. The state standard to allow bathing is a monthly geometric mean less than or equal to 200 cells / 100mL (from 5 or more samples). There is a less stringent standard to allow fishing and boating.
Measures.Sources: New York Harbor Water Quality Survey

Measures.how_calculated: The number of NYC drinking water analyses that are below the NYS maximum contaminant level (MCL) for 227 different contaminants tested throughout the year, divided by the total number of analyses performed throughout the year; expressed as a percent, with a maximum value of 100%. The NYC Department of Environmental Protection performs over 10,000 drinking water analyses monthly.
Measures.Sources: New York City Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) Drinking Water Supply and Quality Report

Measures.how_calculated: Automobile traffic is calculated by summing data reported in the New York Metropolitan Transportation Council's (NYMTC) annual hub-bound (Manhattan below 60th St) report, the NYC Department of Transportation’s (DOT) screenline reports, and annual bridge traffic data. The NYMTC and NYC DOT traffic and screenline reports are manual counts that are modeled in order to extrapolate throughout the year. Transit ridership is calculated from NYC transit subway and bus boarding data, and includes bicycle ridership as estimated from NYC DOT bicycle screenline (boundary) counts and NYMTC annual hub-bound reports. Both numbers are indexed so that their volume percentage in the year 2000 equals 100.
Measures.Sources: New York City Department of Transportation Sustainable Streets Index

IndicatorName: Modal Shift - Travel to the Central Business District

Measures.how_calculated: Number of trips to the central business district (Manhattan below 60th street) on a typical fall morning by transit (bus, subway, railroad, passenger ferry, tram) or bicycle, divided by the total number of automobile, taxi, van and truck trips; expressed as a percent.
Measures.Sources: New York Metropolitan Transportation Council (NYMTC) Hub Bound Travel Report

Measures.how_calculated: The total number of miles (in millions) that transit (public transportation) vehicles (subway cars, rail cars, buses, ferry boats, van pools, trams, para-transit vehicles) are scheduled to travel or actually travel while in revenue service. This number combines all transit agencies in the New York metropolitan area, including non-city agencies that provide significant transit service to and from the city (e.g., Long Island Rail Road). Vehicle revenue miles do not include situations when a bus or subway car travels without passengers back to a storage depot.
Measures.Sources: National Transit Database

IndicatorName: Adults without a Smoke-Free Home Policy
IndicatorDescription: A smoke-free home policy can limit people's exposure to secondhand smoke, which is especially dangerous to children.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults in an area without a policy that prohibits smoking anywhere in the home, divided by all adults in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults without a policy that prohibits smoking anywhere in the home, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults who report current, active smoking, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults in an area who report current, active smoking, divided by all adults in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorName: Adults Reporting Secondhand Smoke at Work

Measures.how_calculated:
Estimated number of adults exposed to second-hand smoke at work, rounded to the nearest 1,000.

 

Adults who are exposed to second-hand smoke all or most of the time at work are considered to be exposed to second-hand smoke at work.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated:
Estimated number of adults in an area exposed to second-hand smoke at work, divided by all adults in the area; expressed as percent.

 

Adults who are exposed to second-hand smoke all or most of the time at work are considered to be exposed to second-hand smoke at work.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of high school students who smoked cigarettes on one or more of the past 30 days, rounded to the nearest 1,000.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of high school students who smoked cigarettes on one or more of the past 30 days, divided by total number of high school students; expressed as a percent.

IndicatorDescription: Fine particles are emitted by vehicles, building boilers, and other combustion - and are a major form of air pollution that harms health.

Measures.how_calculated: Air samples collected at specific NYCCAS monitoring sites along with information about emissions sources were incorporated into a statistical model that predicted pollutant concentrations at all locations in NYC for the specified time period. The results were then assigned to the appropriate NYC neighborhood and averaged. In NYC, fine particulate matter is measured in units of micrograms per cubic meter of air.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Air Survey

The results were then assigned to the appropriate NYC neighborhood and the 10th percentile identified. In NYC, fine particulate matter is measured in units of micrograms per cubic meter of air.

Measures.MeasurementType: Average Annual Number Less Than 15 Yrs Old
Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of resident children, less than 15 years old, diagnosed with leukemia over the 5 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.MeasurementType: Age Adjusted Rate Less Than 15 Yrs Old
Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of resident children, less than 15 years old, diagnosed with leukemia over the 5 year period, divided by the corresponding age-specific intercensal population estimates (from NYS DOH). The resulting age-specific rates are multiplied by the proportion of the US Census 2000 standard population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of these weighted rates; expressed as cases per 1,000,000 children.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.how_calculated: Samples are collected from entry points to the drinking water distribution system. Samples may not be required every year; the most recent available sample result is used to calculate the average. If a concentration is below the limit of detection (LOD), a value equal to one half the LOD is assigned. Total concentrations are averaged over the year and compared to the Maximum Contaminant Level (MCL), which is the highest level of a contamimant that is allowed in drinking water, according to regulatory standards.
Measures.Sources: New York State Safe Drinking Water Information System

Measures.how_calculated: Samples are collected from entry points to the drinking water distribution system. Samples may not be required every year; the most recent available sample result is used to calculate the maximum concentration. If a concentration is below the limit of detection (LOD), a value equal to one half the LOD is assigned. The maximum total concentration is identified for each year and compared to the Maximum Contaminant Level (MCL), which is the highest level of a contamimant that is allowed in drinking water, according to regulatory standards.
Measures.Sources: New York State Safe Drinking Water Information System

Measures.how_calculated: The number of nitrate samples taken at entry points to the distribution system.
Measures.Sources: New York State Safe Drinking Water Information System

Measures.how_calculated: Number of sampling locations.
Measures.Sources: New York State Safe Drinking Water Information System

Measures.how_calculated: The highest level of nitrate that is allowed in drinking water, according to regulatory standards.
Measures.Sources: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)

Measures.how_calculated: Samples are collected from the drinking water distribution system, and concentrations of trichloroacetic acid, dichloroacetic acid, monochloroacetic acid, dibromoacetic acid and monobromoacetic acid are summed within samples to derive a measure of total total haloacetic acids (five) (HAA5). If a concentration is below the limit of detection (LOD), a value equal to one half the LOD is assigned. Total concentrations are averaged over the year.
Measures.Sources: New York State Safe Drinking Water Information System

Measures.how_calculated: Samples are collected from the drinking water distribution system, and concentrations of trichloroacetic acid, dichloroacetic acid, monochloroacetic acid, dibromoacetic acid and monobromoacetic acid are summed within samples to derive a measure of total total haloacetic acids (five) (HAA5). If a concentration is below the limit of detection (LOD), a value equal to one half the LOD is assigned. The maximum total concentration is identified for each year.
Measures.Sources: New York State Safe Drinking Water Information System

Measures.how_calculated: The number of total haloacetic acids (five) (HAA5) samples taken throughout the distribution system.
Measures.Sources: New York State Safe Drinking Water Information System

Measures.how_calculated: Number of sampling total haloacetic acids (five) (HAA5) locations.
Measures.Sources: New York State Safe Drinking Water Information System

Measures.how_calculated: The highest level of total haloacetic acids (five) (HAA5) that is allowed in drinking water, according to regulatory standards.
Measures.Sources: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)

Measures.how_calculated: Samples are collected from the drinking water distribution system, and concentrations of trichloroacetic acid, dichloroacetic acid, monochloroacetic acid, dibromoacetic acid and monobromoacetic acid are summed within samples to derive a measure of total total haloacetic acids (five) (HAA5). If a concentration is below the limit of detection (LOD), a value equal to one half the LOD is assigned. The maximum total concentration is identified for each quarter.
Measures.Sources: New York State Safe Drinking Water Information System

Measures.how_calculated: The highest level of total haloacetic acids (five) (HAA5) that is allowed in drinking water, according to regulatory standards.

If a concentration is below the limit of detection (LOD), a value equal to one half the LOD is assigned. Total concentrations are averaged for each quarter.

If a concentration is below the limit of detection (LOD), a value equal to one half the LOD is assigned. Total concentrations are averaged over the year.

IndicatorName: Asthma Emergency Department Visits (Children 0 to 4 Yrs Old)

Measures.how_calculated:
Number of asthma-related emergency department (ED) visits among NYC resident children up to 4 years old.

 

ED visits include both patients who are treated and released in the ED (outpatients) and who are admitted as inpatients through the emergency department.

 

An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Measures.how_calculated:
Number of asthma-related emergency department (ED) visits among NYC resident children up to 4 years old, divided by the population of children up to 4 years old, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents.

 

ED visits include both patients who are treated and released in the ED (outpatients) and who are admitted as inpatients through the emergency department.

 

An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adult males who reported having more  than 2 alcoholic beverages per day and adult woman having more than 1 drink per day, rounded to the nearest 1,000. Adults are age 18 years and older.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of public high school students who reported having at least one alcoholic beverages on one or more of the past 30 days, divided by the total number of public high school students; expressed as a percent.

Measures.Sources: New York City Youth Risk Behavioral Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Number of currently operating restaurants with an "A" grade in the window.

IndicatorDescription: Whether people perceive their neighborhood as safe can affect whether they will spend time outside, use parks, and use active and sustainable forms of transportation. It can also affect mental well-being.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults who reported living in a neighborhood safe from crime rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults who reported living in a neighborhood safe from crime, divided by all adults in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of deaths during warm season months of May-September with an underlying or contributing cause that includes excessive natural heat (ICD10 code X30) and effects of heat and light (ICD10 code T67), among NYC residents. This number includes only deaths directly attributed to heat on death certificates, which represent a small proportion of all heat-related deaths. Heat can exacerbate chronic conditions, resulting in death from natural causes that may not be labeled as heat-related on a death certificate (also called "excess mortality.") More information about excess mortality associated with extreme heat in NYC is available here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

IndicatorDescription: ED visits due to heat stress represent part of the public health burden of extreme heat.

Measures.how_calculated:
The number of NYC residents treated in a NYC emergency department (ED) during the months of May-September for the effects of heat and light due to weather conditions or undetermined cause. Residents with a diagnosis of excessive heat due to non-environmental conditions were excluded.  Data are based on date of visit and include those with a diagnosis of heat-related illness, even if that was not the principal diagnosis. The data also include patients admitted to the hospital after being treated in an emergency department. 

   

Notes: The coding system used to represent diagnoses changed in October 2015. Cases occuring before October 1, 2015 are represented by International Classification of Diseases (ICD), 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) codes 992.0-992.9, E900.0 or E900.9. Cases admitted on or after October 1, 2015, are represented by the ICD, 10th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) codes T67, X30, X32.  Cases with diagnoses represented by ICD-9-CM code E900.1 (if admitted before October 1, 2015) or ICD-10-CM code W92 (if admitted on or after October 1, 2015) were excluded. Because of the October 1, 2015 change in diagnostic codes from ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM, changes in numbers and rates over time should be interpreted with caution because they may be in part due to changes in the coding system.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Measures.how_calculated:
The number of NYC residents treated in a NYC emergency department (ED) during the months of May-September for the effects of heat and light due to weather conditions or undetermined cause. Residents with a diagnosis of excessive heat due to non-environmental conditions were excluded. Data are based on date of visit and include those with a diagnosis of heat-related illness, even if that was not the principal diagnosis. The data also include patients admitted to the hospital after being treated in an emergency department. 

  

Counts are divided by the population using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates and expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.

 

Notes: The coding system used to represent diagnoses changed in October 2015. Cases occuring before October 1, 2015 are represented by International Classification of Diseases (ICD), 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) codes 992.0-992.9, E900.0 or E900.9. Cases admitted on or after October 1, 2015, are represented by the ICD, 10th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) codes T67, X30, X32.  Cases with diagnoses represented by ICD-9-CM code E900.1 (if admitted before October 1, 2015) or ICD-10-CM code W92 (if admitted on or after October 1, 2015) were excluded. Because of the October 1, 2015 change in diagnostic codes from ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM, changes in numbers and rates over time should be interpreted with caution because they may be in part due to changes in the coding system.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data; United States Census

Measures.how_calculated:
The number of NYC residents treated in a NYC emergency department (ED) during the months of May-September for the effects of heat and light due to weather conditions or undetermined cause. Residents with a diagnosis of excessive heat due to non-environmental conditions were excluded. Data are based on date of visit and include those with a diagnosis of heat-related illness, even if that was not the principal diagnosis. The data also include patients admitted to the hospital after being treated in an emergency department. 

  

Counts are summed by 5-year age groups and divided by the population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.

 

Notes: The coding system used to represent diagnoses changed in October 2015. Cases occuring before October 1, 2015 are represented by International Classification of Diseases (ICD), 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) codes 992.0-992.9, E900.0 or E900.9. Cases admitted on or after October 1, 2015, are represented by the ICD, 10th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) codes T67, X30, X32.  Cases with diagnoses represented by ICD-9-CM code E900.1 (if admitted before October 1, 2015) or ICD-10-CM code W92 (if admitted on or after October 1, 2015) were excluded. Because of the October 1, 2015 change in diagnostic codes from ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM, changes in numbers and rates over time should be interpreted with caution because they may be in part due to changes in the coding system.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data; United States Census

Measures.how_calculated: Number of NYC nonfatal hospitalizations related to bicycle injuries among all ages was identified using the following ICD10-CM injury codes: V01-V99. Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. Citywide totals include both NYC residents and non-residents.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS), 2016, updated January 2018.

Measures.how_calculated: Counts were calculated as described above and summed within five age groups (0-17, 18-24, 25-44, 45-64, 65+) and divided by the population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates, expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) inpatient data 2016, updated January 2018. NYC DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau interpolated intercensal population estimates, 2018, updated September 2019.

IndicatorName: Adult Consumption of 1 or More Sugary Drinks Per Day

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults who, on average reported having consumed one or more sugary drinks per day. Sugary drinks include soda, sweetened iced tea, sports drinks, fruit punch, and other fruit flavored drinks. (One drink equals 12-ounces.) Diet soda, sugar free drinks, 100% juice, and seltzer are not included.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults who, on average reported having consumed one or more sugary drinks per day, divided by all adults in the area; expressed as a percent. Sugary drinks include soda, sweetened iced tea, sports drinks, fruit punch, and other fruit flavored drinks. (One drink equals 12 ounces). Diet soda, sugar free drinks, 100% juice, and seltzer are not included.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorName: Youth Consumption of 1 or More Sugary Drinks Per Day

Sugary drinks include soda, sweetened iced tea, sports drinks, fruit punch, and other fruit flavored drinks. (One drink equals 12 ounces). Diet soda, sugar free drinks, 100% juice, and seltzer are not included.
Measures.Sources: New York City Youth Risk Behavioral Survey
