IndicatorName: Adults Reporting Mold in the Home
IndicatorDescription: Mold can worsen respiratory conditions like asthma, and indicate maintenance deficiencies in a building.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults reporting damp spots or mold in at least one room in their building, excluding the bathroom, in the past 30 days.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults reporting damp spots or mold in at least one room in their building, excluding the bathroom, in the past 30 days, expressed as a percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorName: Adults Reporting Air Conditioning in the Home

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults who reported having a functioning air conditioner in any room in their home, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults who reported having a functioning air conditioner in any room in their home, divided by the number of adults in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorName: Adults Reporting Mice in the Home
IndicatorDescription: Mice or rats in the home are a source of household allergens connected to the developement of asthma and exacerbation of asthma symptoms. They may also indicate other health-threatening maintenance deficiencies.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults reporting mice or rats inside their home in the past 30 days, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults reporting mice or rats inside their home in the past 30 days, divided by the number of adults in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorDescription: Estimating deaths that can be linked to PM2.5 is a way to understand how air pollution increases mortality.

Measures.MeasurementType: Estimated Annual Rate - Adults 30 Yrs and Older
Measures.how_calculated: Estimated annual number of all-cause deaths associated with the difference in air quality for indicator years relative to modeled natural background. Estimate is calculated using the chronic all-cause mortality risk estimate from a comprehensive study by Krewski et al 2009. The rate is the number of deaths attributable to PM2.5 among residents (30 years and older), divided by the population of residents (30 years and older) expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics; United States Census ; USEPA Air Quality System; Krewski D, et al. (2009) HEI Research Report 140. Health Effects Institute, Boston, MA

Measures.MeasurementType: Estimated Annual Number - Adults 30 Yrs and Older
Measures.how_calculated: Estimated annual number of all-cause deaths associated with the difference in air quality for indicator years relative to modeled natural background. Estimate is calculated using the chronic all-cause mortality risk estimate from a comprehensive study by Krewski et al 2009.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics; United States Census ; USEPA Air Quality System; Krewski D, et al. (2009) HEI Research Report 140. Health Effects Institute, Boston, MA

IndicatorName: Traffic Density- Annual Vehicle Miles Traveled for Cars
IndicatorDescription: Traffic density is a measure of  the average number of vehicles that occupy specified area. Traffic density can influence health as a source of air pollution and traffic-related injuries.

Measures.how_calculated: The average number of cars traveling on a road segment on any given day during the year was estimated for each segment in a geography. The number of cars was multiplied by length of road segment to arrive at a daily vehicle-miles measure for that segment. The daily vehicle-miles measures were summed across all segments in a geography and then multiplied by 365 to arrive at an annual measure. Vehicle-miles are expressed in millions per square kilomete
Measures.Sources: New York Metropolitan Transportation Council Best Practice Model

IndicatorDescription: PM2.5-attributable asthma ED visits represent part of the health burden imposed by fine particle air pollution.

Measures.MeasurementType: Estimated Annual Rate- Children 0 to 17 Yrs Old
Measures.how_calculated: Estimate is based on the number of emergency department (ED) visits for asthma associated with the difference in air quality for indicator years relative to modeled natural background. Estimate is calculated using the acute risk of emergency department visits for asthma from the Ito K et al 2007 study conducted on NYC residents.  Neighborhood estimates expressed as annual cases per 100,000 residents under 18 years of age.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS); US Census; USEPA Air Quality System; Ito K et al. (2007) J Expo Sci Environ Epidemiol 17:S45–S60

Neighborhood estimates expressed as annual cases per 100,000 residents over 18 years of Age.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS); US Census; USEPA Air Quality System; Ito K et al. (2007) J Expo Sci Environ Epidemiol 17:S45–S60

IndicatorName: PM2.5-Attributable Respiratory Hospitalizations (Adults 20 Yrs and Older)
IndicatorDescription: Estimating hospitalizations that can be linked to PM2.5 is a way to understand how air pollution impacts public health.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimate is based on the number of hospitalizations for respiratory causes associated with the difference in air quality for indicator years relative to modeled natural background. Estimate is calculated using the acute risk of hospitalizations for all respiratory causes from the Moolgavkar 2000 study conducted on Los Angeles residents between 20-64 years of age and the Zanobetti et al 2009 study in 26 US communities of residents over 65 years of age. Neighborhood estimates expressed as annual cases per 100,000 residents over 20 years of Age.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS); US Census; USEPA Air Quality System; Moolgavkar SH (2000) Inhal Toxicol 12(Supp 4):75–90; Zanobetti etal.(2009) Environ Hlth 8:58. doi:10.1186/1476-069X-8-58

Measures.how_calculated: Estimate is based on the number of hospitalizations for respiratory causes associated with the difference in air quality for indicator years relative to modeled natural background. Estimate is calculated using the acute risk of hospitalizations for all respiratory causes from the Moolgavkar 2000 study conducted on Los Angeles residents between 20-64 years of age and the Zanobetti et al 2009 study in 26 US communities of residents over 65 years of age.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS); US Census; USEPA Air Quality System; Moolgavkar SH (2000) Inhal Toxicol 12(Supp 4):75–90; Zanobetti etal.(2009) Environ Hlth 8:58. doi:10.1186/1476-069X-8-58

IndicatorName: PM2.5-Attributable Cardiovascular Hospitalizations (Adults 40 Yrs and Older)
IndicatorDescription: PM2.5-attributable cardiovascular hospitalizations represent part of the health burden imposed by fine particle air pollution.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimate is based on the number of hospitalizations for cardiovascular causes associated with the difference in air quality for indicator years relative to natural background (modeled air quality levels under no man-made air pollution emissions). Estimate is calculated using the acute risk of hospitalizations for all cardiovascular causes from the Ito K et al 2010 study conducted on New York City residents above 40 years of age. Neighborhood estimates expressed as annual cases per 100,000 residents over 40 years of age.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS); US Census; US EPA Air Quality System; Ito K et al (2011) Environ Hlth Persp, 119(4):467-473

Measures.how_calculated: Estimate is based on the number of hospitalizations for cardiovascular causes associated with the difference in air quality for indicator years relative to natural background (modeled air quality levels under no man-made air pollution emissions). IndicatorDescription: Health insurance coverage is associated with numerous beneficial health effects. Those with health insurance are more likely to have a regular doctor, receive preventive care services, better manage chronic health conditions, have longer life expectancy, and more.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults who reported having any kind of health insurance coverage, including private health insurance, prepaid plans such as H-M-Os or government plans such as Medicare or Medicaid, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults who reported having any kind of health insurance coverage, including private health insurance, prepaid plans such as H-M-Os or government plans such as Medicare or Medicaid; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorDescription:
Walkability indices summarize built environment features believed to promote walking, focusing on neighborhood infrastructure. Some potentially important characteristics are usually not included, such as neighborhood safety or attractiveness, like number of street trees.

For this index, higher scores indicate greater walkability. NYC neighborhoods range in walkability index (infrastructure) score from -4.0 to 9.4, with zero representing an approximate average for the City as a whole.

Measures.how_calculated:
Z-scores were calculated and summed across indicators of residential population density (density of population per total residential land area); intersection density; an entropy measure of land use based on the distribution of building floor area among 5 land-use types (education, entertainment, residential (single- and multi-family), retail, and office); the ratio of retail building floor area to retail land area; and subway stop density. This scale is a variation of Frank's Walkability Index.

Click here for a full description of the Walkability Index (Infrastructure).

For more information, visit http://beh.columbia.edu/.
Measures.Sources: The Built Environment & Health Project (BEH), Columbia University

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults who reported experiencing noise disruption three or more times per week, rounded to the nearest 1,000. Disruptive noise exposure is any ambient noise from outside the home that disrupts activities - such as watching television, listening to the radio, having a conversation, or sleeping - of the person who hears it.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults who reported experiencing noise disruption three or more times per week, divided by the number of adults in the area; expressed as percent. Disruptive noise exposure is any ambient noise from outside the home that disrupts activities - such as watching television, listening to the radio, having a conversation, or sleeping - of the person who hears it.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorName: Fall-related emergency department visits among older adults

Measures.how_calculated: Number of NYC emergency department visits related to falls among adults aged 65 years and older was identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: V00.1(1-5,8)1; V00.2(1,2,8)1; V00.3(1,2,8)1; V00.8(1-3,9)1; W00.0-W15; W16.0(1-3)2; W16.1(1-3)2; W16.3(1-3)2; W16.42x; W16.5(1-3)2; W16.6(1,2,7)2; W16.7(1,2)2; W16.8(1-3)2; W16.92x, W17; W18.1(1,2)x; W18.2xx; W18.3(0,1,9)x; W19. Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. All figures include NYC residents only.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) emergency department data, 2016, updated January 2018.

Measures.how_calculated: Age-adjusted rates were calculated per 100,000 population 65 years and older weighted to the 2016 NYC DOHMH population estimates using the following age groups for weighting: 65-74, 75-84, and 85+ years old. Numerator consists of NYC hospitalizations related to falls among adults aged 65 years and older, identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: V00.1(1-5,8)1; V00.2(1,2,8)1; V00.3(1,2,8)1; V00.8(1-3,9)1; W00.0-W15; W16.0(1-3)2; W16.1(1-3)2; W16.3(1-3)2; W16.42x; W16.5(1-3)2; W16.6(1,2,7)2; W16.7(1,2)2; W16.8(1-3)2; W16.92x, W17; W18.1(1,2)x; W18.2xx; W18.3(0,1,9)x; W19. Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. All figures include NYC residents only.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) emergency department data, 2016, updated January 2018. ; NYC DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau interpolated intercensal population estimates, 2016. Updated September 2017.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of NYC hospitalizations related to falls among adults aged 65 years and older was identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: V00.1(1-5,8)1; V00.2(1,2,8)1; V00.3(1,2,8)1; V00.8(1-3,9)1; W00.0-W15; W16.0(1-3)2; W16.1(1-3)2; W16.3(1-3)2; W16.42x; W16.5(1-3)2; W16.6(1,2,7)2; W16.7(1,2)2; W16.8(1-3)2; W16.92x, W17; W18.1(1,2)x; W18.2xx; W18.3(0,1,9)x; W19. Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. All figures include NYC residents only.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) emergency department data, 2016, updated January 2018.

Measures.how_calculated: Age-specific rates were calculated per 100,000 population 65 years and older. Numerator consists of NYC hospital admissions related to falls among adults aged 65 years and older, identified using ICD10-CM codes: V00.1(1-5,8)1; V00.2(1,2,8)1; V00.3(1,2,8)1; V00.8(1-3,9)1; W00.0-W15; W16.0(1-3)2; W16.1(1-3)2; W16.3(1-3)2; W16.42x; W16.5(1-3)2; W16.6(1,2,7)2; W16.7(1,2)2; W16.8(1-3)2; W16.92x, W17; W18.1(1,2)x; W18.2xx; W18.3(0,1,9)x; W19. Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. All figures include NYC residents only.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) inpatient data, 2016, updated January 2018. NYC DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau interpolated intercensal population estimates, 2016, updated September 2017.

Measures.how_calculated: Age-adjusted rates were calculated per 100,000 population 65 years and older weighted to the 2016 NYC DOHMH population estimates using the following age groups for weighting: 65-74, 75-84, and 85+ years old. Numerator consists of NYC hospitalizations related to falls among adults aged 65 years and older, identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: V00.1(1-5,8)1; V00.2(1,2,8)1; V00.3(1,2,8)1; V00.8(1-3,9)1; W00.0-W15; W16.0(1-3)2; W16.1(1-3)2; W16.3(1-3)2; W16.42x; W16.5(1-3)2; W16.6(1,2,7)2; W16.7(1,2)2; W16.8(1-3)2; W16.92x, W17; W18.1(1,2)x; W18.2xx; W18.3(0,1,9)x; W19. Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. All figures include NYC residents only.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) emergency department data, 2016, updated January 2018. ; NYC DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau interpolated intercensal population estimates, 2016. Updated September 2017.

IndicatorDescription: Surface temperatures in NYC may vary as a function of vegetative land cover, which promotes cooling, or cover by paved roads, sidewalks, and buildings, which retain heat.

Measures.how_calculated: Daytime landsat thermal data on surface, July 17, 2018, averaged spatially.
Measures.Sources: U. S. Geological Survey

IndicatorDescription: Vegetative cover is the land covered by trees, grass, or other plants. This area is not covered by a hard surface such as paved roads, sidewalks, or buildings. Vegetative cover tends to reduce temperatures in the immediate area.

Measures.how_calculated: Spatial information classifying ground cover is used to calculate a percentage of each geographic area that is covered in vegetation. See this paper for classification methods discussion.
Measures.Sources: University of Vermont remote sensing LiDAR data, assessed using methodology described in: MacFaden, S.W., O’Neil-Dunne, J.P.M., Royer, A.R., Lu, J.W.T., & Rundle, A.G. (2012). High-resolution tree canopy mapping for New York City using LiDAR and object-based image analysis. Journal of Applied Remote Sensing, 6(1).

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults (aged 18 and over) who reported having a personal doctor or health care provider rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults who reported having a personal doctor or health care provider, divided by all adults in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorName: Adults 65+ Reporting Air Conditioning in the Home
IndicatorDescription: Adults over the age of 65 are more vulnerable to hot weather and heat stress. Air conditioning (AC) can substantially reduce the risk of heat stroke and other heat-related illness.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults age 65 years or older who reported having a functioning air conditioner in any room in their home, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults age 65 years or older who reported having a functioning air conditioner in any room in their home, divided by the number of adults aged 65 years or older in the area; expressed as percent
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorDescription: The number of trees and the area shaded by them influences many neighborhood factors, such as attractiveness and lower summer temperatures that, in turn, encourage residents and visitors to walk and do other physical activity. “Tree canopy cover” measures the percent of a neighborhood that is covered (or shaded) by trees.

Measures.how_calculated: Tree canopy cover represents a 'top down' mapping perspective in which tree canopy over-hanging city features (such as sidewalks) is measured. The percent is calculated by dividing the area of tree canopy in km2 within the UHF neighborhood by the total land area (excluding inland water bodies). Higher percentages indicate greater tree canopy cover, with zero representing no tree canopy cover.
Measures.Sources: The Built Environment & Health Project (BEH), Columbia University

IndicatorDescription: Many New Yorkers rely on the subway as their primary mode of transportation. Neighborhoods with greater subway access tend to have more foot traffic, making surrounding real estate highly desirable for residents and business. Subway use encourages active transportation (walking, biking), which improves the health of residents.

Measures.how_calculated:
Subway station density measure takes into account multiple route-transfer opportunities at one subway station and each stop is counted only once regardless of how many route-transfer opportunities are available at any given subway station. Density is calculated by dividing the count of MTA subways stations as of 2012 by the total land area in km2 of the UHF neighborhood (excluding inland water bodies).

For more information, visit http://beh.columbia.edu/.
Measures.Sources: The Built Environment & Health Project (BEH), Columbia University

IndicatorName: Carbon Monoxide Incidents without a Detector (3 Year Avg.)
IndicatorDescription: Carbon monoxide detectors are required in NYC homes by law. Failure to provide or maintain a detector can put residents at risk for carbon monoxide poisoning and death.

Measures.how_calculated: A 3-year average annual number of carbon monoxide incidents where FDNY measured at least 1 ppm at the scene, and there was no detector (alarm) or alarm did not go off.
Measures.Sources: Fire Department of New York City (FDNY) Carbon Monoxide Incidents

Measures.how_calculated: A 3-year average annual rate of carbon monoxide incidents where FDNY measured at least 1 ppm at the scene, and there was no detector (alarm) or alarm did not go off; expressed as incidents per 10,000 buildings.
Measures.Sources: Fire Department of New York City (FDNY) Carbon Monoxide Incidents

IndicatorName: Walk for Transportation in the Past 7 Days

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults who reported having walked at least 10 minutes to get to and from places, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults who reported having walked at least 10 minutes to get to and from places, divided by all adults in the area; expressed as a percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorName: Bike for Transportation in the Past 7 Days

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults who reported having biked to get to and from places, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults who reported having biked to get to and from places, divided by all adults in the area; expressed as a percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated:
NYC residents admitted to a NYC hospital during the months of October-April for the effects of reduced temperature or excessive or extreme cold due to weather conditions or undetermined cause (International Classification of Diseases, 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) codes 991, E901.0, E901.8, E901.9, or E988.3 if admitted before October 1, 2015; International Classification of Diseases, 10th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) codes X31, T68, T69, T33, T34 if admitted on or after October 1, 2015). Residents with a diagnostic code for excessive cold due to man-made conditions were excluded (ICD-9-CM code E901.1 if admitted before October 1, 2015; ICD-10-CM code W93 if admitted on or after October 1, 2015). Annual data is based on date of admission, and include those who were admitted with a diagnosis of cold-related illness in any principal or other diagnostic field. The data also include patients admitted to the hospital after being treated in an emergency department.

 

Counts are summed by 5-year age groups and divided by the population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data; United States Census

Measures.how_calculated:
NYC residents admitted to a NYC hospital during the months of October-April for the effects of reduced temperature or excessive or extreme cold due to weather conditions or undetermined cause (International Classification of Diseases, 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) codes 991, E901.0, E901.8, E901.9, or E988.3 if admitted before October 1, 2015; International Classification of Diseases, 10th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) codes X31, T68, T69, T33, T34 if admitted on or after October 1, 2015). Residents with a diagnostic code for excessive cold due to man-made conditions were excluded (ICD-9-CM code E901.1 if admitted before October 1, 2015; ICD-10-CM code W93 if admitted on or after October 1, 2015). Annual data is based on date of admission, and include those who were admitted with a diagnosis of cold-related illness in any principal or other diagnostic field. The data also include patients admitted to the hospital after being treated in an emergency department.

 

Note: Because of the October 1, 2015 change in diagnostic codes from ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM, changes in numbers and rates over time should be interpreted with caution because they may be in part due to changes in the coding system.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

IndicatorName: Children under 5 years old in Poverty
IndicatorDescription: Poverty is a major determinant of health, since poverty deprives people of access to health and safety resources.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children who live in a household for whom poverty status is determined, whose annual income falls below twice the federal poverty.
Measures.Sources: American Community Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children in a household whose annual income falls below twice the federal poverty level, divided by the number of children in households for whom poverty status is determined; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: American Community Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Neighborhoods are ranked citywide in 3 groups (tertiles), so that neighborhoods can be grouped and compared.
Measures.Sources: American Community Survey

IndicatorName: Renter-occupied homes with no maintenance deficiencies (TCNY2020)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of renter-occupied households reporting no maintenance deficiencies (heating equipment breakdown, additional heating required, rodent infestation, cracks/holes in the walls, ceilings or floors, broken plaster/peeling paint larger than 8½ x 11 inches, toilet breakdowns, or water leaks from outside the unit).
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of renter-occupied households in an area reporting no maintenance deficiencies (heating equipment breakdown, additional heating required, rodent infestation, cracks/holes in the walls, ceilings or floors, broken plaster/peeling paint larger than 8½ x 11 inches, toilet breakdowns, or water leaks from outside the unit), divided by the number of renter-occupied households in the area; expressed as percent..
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

IndicatorDescription: Sidewalks are a critical component of New York City residents’ commute. Ample sidewalks in neighborhoods are important for commuting, businesses, and physical activity. Greater sidewalk area facilitates safer pedestrian traffic that, in turn, attracts businesses and fosters community. “Sidewalk area” measures the percent of a neighborhood that is covered by sidewalk area.

Measures.how_calculated:
The total sidewalk area (curb-to-building) in km2 within the UHF neighborhood divided by the total land area (excluding inland water bodies). Higher percentages indicate greater sidewalk area, with zero representing no sidewalk area.

For more information, visit http://beh.columbia.edu/.
Measures.Sources: The Built Environment & Health Project (BEH), Columbia University

IndicatorName: Children under 6 years with elevated blood lead levels (BLL)
IndicatorDescription: There is no safe level of lead in the blood. Lead poisoning can cause learning and behavior problems, and delay growth and mental development.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of children less than 6 years old tested in a given year with blood lead levels of 5 mcg/dL or greater. The numbers in this table include all children tested within a given calendar year, regardless of whether they were tested in previous years with the same or different blood lead levels. While children can receive more than one test during the calendar year, children are only counted once using the highest confirmed blood lead level during the calendar year. If the child does not have a confirmed test in a given year, the child’s blood lead level is based on the highest capillary or unknown test type. This measure differs from the number of children newly identified with blood lead levels at or above a certain level reported by the Health Department in other publications. Read more about different measures used by the Health Department for surveillance of childhood lead poisoning.
Measures.Sources: New York City Healthy Homes Program

Measures.how_calculated: Number of children less than 6 years old tested in a given year with blood lead levels of 10 mcg/dL or greater. The numbers in this table include all children tested within a given calendar year, regardless of whether they were tested in previous years with the same or different blood lead levels. While children can receive more than one test during the calendar year, children are only counted once using the highest confirmed blood lead level during the calendar year. If the child does not have a confirmed test in a given year, the child’s blood lead level is based on the highest capillary or unknown test type. This measure differs from the number of children newly identified with blood lead levels of 10 mcg/dL or greater reported by the Health Department in other publications. Read more about different measures used by the Health Department for surveillance of childhood lead poisoning.
Measures.Sources: New York City Healthy Homes Program

Measures.how_calculated: Number of children less than 6 years old tested in a given year with blood lead levels of 15 mcg/dL or greater. The numbers in this table include all children tested within a given calendar year, regardless of whether they were tested in previous years with the same or different blood lead levels. While children can receive more than one test during the calendar year, children are only counted once using the highest confirmed blood lead level during the calendar year. If the child does not have a confirmed test in a given year, the child’s blood lead level is based on the highest capillary or unknown test type. This measure differs from the number of children newly identified with blood lead levels of 15 mcg/dL or greater reported by the Health Department in other publications. Read more about different measures used by the Health Department for surveillance of childhood lead poisoning.
Measures.Sources: New York City Healthy Homes Program

Measures.how_calculated: Number of children less than 6 years old tested in a given year with blood lead levels of 5 mcg/dL or greater, divided by the total number of children less than 6 years old who were tested for lead poisoning in a given year; expressed as cases per 1,000 tested. The numbers in this table include all children tested within a given calendar year, regardless of whether they were tested in previous years with the same or different blood lead levels. While children can receive more than one test during the calendar year, children are only counted once using the highest confirmed blood lead level during the calendar year. If the child does not have a confirmed test in a given year, the child’s blood lead level is based on the highest capillary or unknown test type. This measure differs from the rate of children newly identified with blood lead levels at or above a certain level reported by the Health Department in other publications. Read more about different measures used by the Health Department for surveillance of childhood lead poisoning.
Measures.Sources: New York City Healthy Homes Program

Measures.how_calculated: Number of children less than 6 years old tested in a given year with blood lead levels of 10 mcg/dL or greater, divided by the number of children less than 6 years old who were tested for lead poisoning in a given year; expressed as cases per 1,000 tested. The numbers in this table include all children tested within a given calendar year, regardless of whether they were tested in previous years with the same or different blood lead levels. While children can receive more than one test during the calendar year, children are only counted once using the highest confirmed blood lead level during the calendar year. If the child does not have a confirmed test in a given year, the child’s blood lead level is based on the highest capillary or unknown test type. This measure differs from the rate of children newly identified with blood lead levels at or above 10 mcg/dL reported by the Health Department in other publications. Read more about different measures used by the Health Department for surveillance of childhood lead poisoning.
Measures.Sources: New York City Healthy Homes Program

Measures.how_calculated: Number of children less than 6 years old tested in a given year with blood lead levels of 15 mcg/dL or greater, divided by the number of children less than 6 years old who were tested for lead poisoning in a given year; expressed as cases per 1,000 tested. The numbers in this table include all children tested within a given calendar year, regardless of whether they were tested in previous years with the same or different blood lead levels. While children can receive more than one test during the calendar year, children are only counted once using the highest confirmed blood lead level during the calendar year. If the child does not have a confirmed test in a given year, the child’s blood lead level is based on the highest capillary or unknown test type. This measure differs from the rate of children newly identified with blood lead levels of 15 mcg/dL or greater reported by the Health Department in other publications. Read more about different measures used by the Health Department for surveillance of childhood lead poisoning.
Measures.Sources: New York City Healthy Homes Program

Measures.how_calculated: Children under 6 years of age tested for lead poisoning in a given year. Children may be tested multiple times in a given year but are only counted once. All children are counted regardless of blood specimen type (confirmed or unconfirmed); the number is rounded to the nearest 100. Read more about different measures used by the Health Department for surveillance of childhood lead poisoning.
Measures.Sources: New York City Healthy Homes Program

IndicatorDescription: Air conditioning is an important way to avoid heat stress, especially for persons with limited mobility.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households in an area reporting having functioning air conditioning, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households reporting having functioning air conditioning
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

Measures.MeasurementType: Percent Household Reporting Lack of AC
Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households in an area reporting not having functioning air conditioning, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

IndicatorName: Homes with Grab Bars in Bathroom (among older adult households)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of homes with grab bars in the bathroom, among homes with adults aged 65 years or older.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of homes with grab bars in the bathroom, among homes with adults aged 65 years or older, divided by the estimated number of households with adults aged 65 years or older; expressed as a percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

IndicatorName: Children tested for lead by age 3 years

Measures.how_calculated: Number of children born in New York City to New York City resident mothers tested for lead poisoning before the age of three years. To identify children tested for lead poisoning, birth records for all children born in a given year in New York City to New York City resident mothers were matched to children tested for lead poisoning in the New York City Childhood Lead Registry. Read more about different measures used by the Health Department for surveillance of childhood lead poisoning.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics; New York City Healthy Homes Program

Measures.how_calculated: Number of children born in New York City to New York City resident mothers who were tested for lead poisoning before the age of three years, divided by the number of children born in New York City to New York City resident mothers turning three years old; expressed as percent. Read more about different measures used by the Health Department for surveillance of childhood lead poisoning.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics; New York City Healthy Homes Program

IndicatorDescription: The New York City (NYC) Heat Vulnerability Index (HVI) is a measure of how the risk of heat-related illness or death differs across neighborhoods. Neighborhood risk factors that increase heat- vulnerability in NYC are: less home air conditioning, less green space, hotter surface temperatures, and more residents who are low-income or non-Latinx Black. Differences in these risk factors across neighborhoods are rooted in past and present racism.

Measures.how_calculated:
Each neighborhood receives a score from 1 (lowest risk) to 5 (highest risk) based on a statistical model that uses social and environmental factors to estimate risk of heat-related death across NYC neighborhoods. A low vulnerability score does not mean no risk. Every neighborhood has residents at risk for heat illness and death. Residents who are at highest heat risk are those who do not have or use air conditioning AND are older or have chronic health conditions or serious mental illnesses.

 

To learn more about the HVI calculations, visit the HVI FAQ.

 

Visit www.nyc.gov/health/heat for more information about heat illness and how to prevent it. NYS has its own HVI information.
Measures.Sources: American Community Survey (2013-2017 5-yr estimates); New York City Department of Parks and Recreation (2017); U. S. Geological Survey LandSat (2018); United States Census Housing and Vacancy Survey (2017)

Measures.how_calculated: The highest level of TTHM that is allowed in drinking water according to regulatory standards
Measures.Sources: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)

Measures.how_calculated: Samples are collected from the drinking water distribution system, and concentrations of chloroform, bromodichloromethane, dibromochloromethane, and bromoform are summed within samples to derive a measure of total trihalomethane (TTHM). If a concentration is below the limit of detection (LOD), a value equal to one half the LOD is assigned. Total concentrations are averaged over each quarter.
Measures.Sources: New York State Safe Drinking Water Information System

Measures.how_calculated: Samples are collected from the drinking water distribution system, and concentrations of chloroform, bromodichloromethane, dibromochloromethane, and bromoform are summed within samples to derive a measure of total trihalomethane (TTHM). If a concentration is below the limit of detection (LOD), a value equal to one half the LOD is assigned. The maximum total concentration is identified for each quarter.
Measures.Sources: New York State Safe Drinking Water Information System

Measures.how_calculated: tThe highest level of total trihalomethanes (TTHM) that is allowed in drinking water according to regulatory standards.
Measures.Sources: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)

Measures.how_calculated: Samples are collected from the drinking water distribution system, and concentrations of chloroform, bromodichloromethane, dibromochloromethane, and bromoform are summed within samples to derive a measure of total trihalomethane (TTHM). If a concentration is below the limit of detection (LOD), a value equal to one half the LOD is assigned. The maximum total concentration is identified for each year.
Measures.Sources: New York State Safe Drinking Water Information System

Measures.how_calculated: The number of total trihalomethanes (TTHM) samples taken throughout the distribution system.
Measures.Sources: New York State Safe Drinking Water Information System

Measures.how_calculated: Samples are collected from the drinking water distribution system, and concentrations of chloroform, bromodichloromethane, dibromochloromethane, and bromoform are summed within samples to derive a measure of total trihalomethane (TTHM). If a concentration is below the limit of detection (LOD), a value equal to one half the LOD is assigned. Total concentrations are averaged over the year.
Measures.Sources: New York State Safe Drinking Water Information System

Measures.how_calculated: The number of total trihalomethanes (TTHM) samples taken throughout the distribution system.
Measures.Sources: New York State Safe Drinking Water Information System

IndicatorDescription:
Asbestos is a naturally-occurring mineral which was commonly used as an insulation material until the 1970s. Inhaling high concentrations of asbestos fibers over a long time can produce lung inflammation and scarring resulting in the chronic lung disease called asbestosis, a type of pneumoconiosis. New York City construction, insulation, and shipyard workers who installed, disturbed, or removed asbestos without respiratory protection are at risk. Additionally, smokers who are exposed to asbestos have a greater risk of developing asbestos-related diseases than non-smokers.  

 

Typically it takes more than ten years from the time of exposure before symptoms develop. The use of proper protective masks is key to preventing the disease, since there is no treatment for this condition.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of hospitalizations with an asbestosis ICD-9-CM diagnosis code of 501, among NYC residents aged 15 years or older, over a three-year period, divided by the population of NYC residents aged 15 years or older, expressed as 3-year average annual rate per 100,000 residents.
Measures.Sources: Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System; U.S. Census Bureau Population Estimates (V2016)
Measures.DisplayType: per 100,000 residents aged 15 years or older

Measures.how_calculated: Number of hospitalizations with an asbestosis ICD-9-CM diagnosis code of 501, among NYC residents aged 15 years or older, over a 3-year period.
Measures.Sources: Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System

IndicatorName: Elevated Blood Lead Levels among Persons Aged 16 or Older
IndicatorDescription: In New York City, the most common cause of lead poisoning in non-pregnant adults is from occupational exposure in the construction industry. Workers are exposed by breathing in or ingesting lead dust or fumes during renovations, repairs and demolitions that disturb old, lead based paint. Workers in other industries, as well as hobbyists, may be at risk if they work with lead-containing metal, paint, pigments, ceramic glazes or bullets. Adults can also be exposed to lead through the use of lead-contaminated products, such as certain imported health remedies or medicines, spices, foods, pottery and cosmetics.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of NYC residents aged 16 years or older with blood lead levels (BLL) greater than or equal to 10 micrograms per deciliter over the 3-year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Heavy Metal Registry

Measures.how_calculated: Number of NYC residents aged 16 years and older with blood lead levels greater than or equal to 25 micrograms per deciliter over the 3-year period, divided by the employed NYC population aged 16 years or older in each of the 3 years, expressed as 3-year average annual rate per 100,000 employed persons.
Measures.Sources: New York State Heavy Metal Registry; U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics Current Population Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Number of NYC residents aged 16 years or older with blood lead levels greater than or equal to 25 micrograms per deciliter over the 3-year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Heavy Metal Registry

Measures.how_calculated: Number of NYC residents aged 16 years and older with blood lead levels greater than or equal to 10 micrograms per deciliter over the 3-year period, divided by the employed NYC population aged 16 years or older in each of the 3 years, expressed as 3-year average annual rate per 100,000 employed persons.
Measures.Sources: New York State Heavy Metal Registry; U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics Current Population Survey

IndicatorDescription: Pneumoconiosis is a general term given to any lung disease caused by breathing in certain particles or fibers over a prolonged period. Pneumoconiosis usually results from a workplace exposure  The most common causes of pneumoconiosis include asbestos fibers (asbestosis), silica dust (silicosis), and coal dust (coal workers’ pneumoconiosis or “Black Lung Disease”). There is no cure, but it can be prevented with appropriate respiratory protection.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of hospitalizations with a pneumoconiosis ICD-9-CM diagnosis code 500 - 505 or an ICD-10-CM diagnosis code J60 - J64, among NYC residents aged 15 years or older, divided by the population of NYC residents aged 15 years or older, expressed as 3-year average annual rate per 100,000 residents.
Measures.Sources: Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System; U.S. Census Bureau Population Estimates (V2016)
Measures.DisplayType: per 100,000 residents aged 15 years or older

Measures.how_calculated: Number of hospitalizations with a pneumoconiosis ICD-9-CM diagnosis code 500 - 505 or an ICD-10-CM diagnosis code J60 - J64, among NYC residents aged 15 years or older, over a 3-year period.
Measures.Sources: Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System

IndicatorDescription: Workers’ compensation is a type of insurance that provides medical care for workers who are injured or become ill as a direct result of their job. Hospitalizations billed to workers' compensation represent only a portion of work-related injuries that require hospital care. It is important to realize that workers’ compensation policies vary from state-to-state with respect to the types of workers covered and the types of injuries and illnesses eligible for compensation.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of hospitalizations among employed NYC residents aged 16 years or older with workers’ compensation listed as the primary payer over a 3-year period, divided by the population of employed NYC residents aged 16 years or older in each of these years, expressed as a 3-year average annual rate per 100,000.
Measures.Sources: Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System; U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics Current Population Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Number of hospitalizations among employed NYC residents aged 16 years or older with workers’ compensation listed as the primary payer in hospital discharge data over a 3-year period.
Measures.Sources: Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System

IndicatorDescription:
Fatal work-related injuries include deaths resulting from unintentional injuries such as falls, acute poisonings, and motor vehicle crashes that occur during travel for work, and intentional injuries (i.e., homicides and suicides) that occur at work. Fatal injuries that occur during a person’s commute to or from work are not included.

 

Data on work-related deaths are compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) Census of Fatal Occupational Injuries (CFOI). CFOI produces statistics on fatal work-related injuries by cross-referencing multiple sources, such as death certificates, workers' compensation reports, and Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) investigation reports.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of fatal work-related injuries occurring in NYC and reported to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics Census of Fatal Occupational Injuries.
Measures.Sources: U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics Census of Fatal Occupational Injuries

Measures.how_calculated: Number of fatal work-related injuries occurring in NYC and reported to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, divided by the size of the NYC workforce, expressed as deaths per 10,000 workers.
Measures.Sources: U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics Census of Fatal Occupational Injuries; U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics Current Population Survey

IndicatorName: Work-Related Deaths in the Construction Industry Citywide
IndicatorDescription: The New York City workforce is a diverse one and workplace risks are not distributed equally. Construction is the most dangerous industry in NYC, accounting for nearly a third of work-related injury deaths each year. Falls from scaffolds, ladders and roofs are the most common cause of fatal injuries among construction workers.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of fatal construction injuries occurring in NYC and reported to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics Census of Fatal Occupational Injuries.
Measures.Sources: U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics Census of Fatal Occupational Injuries

Measures.how_calculated: Number of fatal construction injuries occurring in NYC and reported to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, divided by the NYC construction workforce, expressed as deaths per 10,000 workers.
Measures.Sources: U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics Census of Fatal Occupational Injuries; U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics Current Population Survey

IndicatorName: Children under 6 years with elevated blood lead levels by NTA
IndicatorDescription: Children under 6 years of age with blood lead levels (BLL) at or above 5 mcg/dL, by neighborhood tabulation area (NTA). Read more about neighborhood tabulation areas.

Measures.how_calculated:
Sum of the number of children under 6 years of age with blood lead levels (BLL) 5 mcg/dL or greater over the time period, divided by the number of years in the time period. While children can receive more than one test during the calendar year, for this measure children are only counted once per year using the highest confirmed blood lead level during the calendar year. If the child does not have a confirmed test in a given year, the child’s blood lead level is based on the highest capillary or unknown test type. Read more about different measures used by the Health Department for surveillance of childhood lead poisoning.

  • For the purpose of providing data for small geographic areas, multiple years of data were combined to get sufficient numbers of observations to make more reliable estimates for a greater number of neighborhood tabulation areas (NTAs).
  • Annual numbers and rates of children under 6 years of age with elevated blood lead levels at the citywide, borough, and United Hospital Fund neighborhood level are available here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Healthy Homes Program

Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of children under 6 years of age tested for lead poisoning. Children may be tested multiple times in a given year but for this measure are only counted once per year. All children are counted regardless of blood specimen type (confirmed or unconfirmed). Numbers are rounded to nearest 10. Read more about definitions and measures used by the Health Department for surveillance of childhood lead poisoning.
Measures.Sources: New York City Healthy Homes Program

Measures.how_calculated:
Number of children under 6 years of age tested with blood lead levels (BLL) 5 mcg/dL or greater, divided by the total number of children under 6 years of age who were tested; expressed as cases per 1,000 tested. While children can receive more than one test during the calendar year, for this measure children are only counted once per year using the highest confirmed blood lead level during the calendar year. If the child does not have a confirmed test in a given year, the child’s blood lead level is based on the highest capillary or unknown test type. Read more about different measures used by the Health Department for surveillance of childhood lead poisoning.

  • For the purpose of providing data for small geographic areas, multiple years of data were combined to get sufficient numbers of observations to make more reliable estimates for a greater number of neighborhood tabulation areas (NTAs). 
  • Annual numbers and rates of children under 6 years of age with elevated blood lead levels at the citywide, borough, and United Hospital Fund neighborhood level are available here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Healthy Homes Program

IndicatorDescription:
Babesiosis is a rare, sometimes severe or fatal tick-borne disease caused by Babesia microti, a protozoan parasite that infects red blood cells. Babesiosis is transmitted by the bite of an infected blacklegged tick, Ixodes scapularis, the same tick that transmits Lyme disease and anaplasmosis.  Most patients acquire this disease while traveling to endemic areas outside NYC. However, there has been an increase in the number of cases with no history of travel to endemic areas, primarily in Staten Island, as well as isolated cases in the Bronx and Queens. Babesiosis can also be transmitted through transfused blood products.

 

For more information   

NYC DOHMH Babesiosis Page

NYC DOHMH Zoonotic and Vector-borne Diseases 

CDC Babesiosis 

National Surveillance Babesiosis Case Definition

IndicatorDescription:
Each component of the criminal justice continuum - from arrest to re-entry - carries various health consequences, and a growing body of literature has documented severe adverse health outcomes associated with incarceration on the individual, their families, and neighbourhoods. 

("Structural Racism and Health Inequities in the USA: Evidence and Interventions”, by Zinzi D Bailey, ScD; Professor Nancy Krieger, PhD; Madina Agénor, ScD; Jasmine Graves, MPH; Natalia Linos, ScD; and Dr. Mary T. Bassett, MD)

Measures.how_calculated:
Crude rate of of incarcerated adults in NYC Department of Correction facilities per 1,000 population ages 18 and older.

 

Addresses at admission to New York City Department of Correction facilities were geocoded; 69% of all records could be geocoded to a valid NTA. Data were limited to those ages 18 years of age and older and deduplicated by individuals' unique ID numbers and NTAs of residence. The six years of count data were annualized by dividing by six.
Measures.Sources: New York City Department of Correction

Measures.how_calculated:
Estimated number of people in the civilian labor force (16 years and older) who are unemployed. 

 

All civilians 16 years old and over are classified as unemployed if they (1) were neither "at work" nor "with a job but not at work" during the reference week, and (2) were looking for work during the last 4 weeks, and (3) were available to accept a job. Also included as unemployed are civilians who did not work at all during the reference week, were waiting to be called back to a job from which they had been laid off, and were available for work except for temporary illness.
Measures.Sources: American Community Survey

Measures.how_calculated:
Estimated number of people in the civilian labor force (16 years and older) who are unemployed, divided by the total civilian labor force; expressed as percent.

 

All civilians 16 years old and over are classified as unemployed if they (1) were neither "at work" nor "with a job but not at work" during the reference week, and (2) were looking for work during the last 4 weeks, and (3) were available to accept a job. Also included as unemployed are civilians who did not work at all during the reference week, were waiting to be called back to a job from which they had been laid off, and were available for work except for temporary illness.
Measures.Sources: American Community Survey

IndicatorDescription: West Nile virus (WNV) is an arbovirus which is transmitted through the bite of infected mosquitoes; in NYC, the mosquitoes that transmit WNV are primarily Culex pipiens as well as Culex restuans and Culex salinarius. While most people who are infected will not go on to develop symptoms, about 20% can experience mild or moderate illness and more rarely, neuroinvasive disease which can present as encephalitis or meningitis.  Most of the West Nile disease cases detected by the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene represent neuroinvasive disease as these patients are more likely to seek care.   More specific West Nile viral disease data is available on the Health Department website.

Measures.how_calculated:
Number of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)-related hospitalizations among NYC residents aged 25 years and older, summed within 5-year age groups, and divided by the population in each age group using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents.

 

Hospitalizations include ICD-9 principal diagnosis codes 490 (bronchitis, not specified as acute or chronic), 491 (chronic bronchitis), 492 (emphysema), 496 (chronic airway obstruction, not elsewhere classified), 493.2 (chronic obstructive asthma) or ICD-10 principal diagnosis codes J40 (bronchitis, not specified as acute or chronic), J41-J42 (chronic bronchitis), J43 (emphysema), or J44 (other COPD). Cases with 493.2 are excluded if none of the secondary diagnosis fields contain 490-492 or 496.

 

New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems differ in how they classify COPD, data are not comparable before and after 2015. Data from 2015 are not shown because they contain a combination of ICD-9 and ICD-10 principal diagnosis codes.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Hospitalizations include ICD-9 principal diagnosis codes 490 (bronchitis, not specified as acute or chronic), 491 (chronic bronchitis), 492 (emphysema), 496 (chronic airway obstruction, not elsewhere classified), 493.2 (chronic obstructive asthma) or ICD-10 principal diagnosis codes J40 (bronchitis, not specified as acute or chronic), J41-J42 (chronic bronchitis), J43 (emphysema), or J44 (other COPD). Cases with 493.2 are excluded if none of the secondary diagnosis fields contain 490-492 or 496. 

 

New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems differ in how they classify adult asthma, data are not comparable before and after 2015. Data from 2015 are not shown because they contain a combination of ICD-9 and ICD-10 principal diagnosis codes.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

IndicatorName: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease Emergency Department Visits

Measures.how_calculated:
Number of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)-related emergency department (ED) visits among NYC residents aged 25 years and older, summed within 5-year age groups, and divided by the population in each age group using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents.

 

ED visits include both patients who are treated and released in the ED (outpatients) and who are admitted as inpatients through the emergency department.

 

ED vists include ICD-9 principal diagnosis codes 490 (bronchitis, not specified as acute or chronic), 491 (chronic bronchitis), 492 (emphysema), 496 (chronic airway obstruction, not elsewhere classified), 493.2 (chronic obstructive asthma) or ICD-10 principal diagnosis codes J40 (bronchitis, not specified as acute or chronic), J41-J42 (chronic bronchitis), J43 (emphysema), or J44 (other COPD). Cases with 493.2 are excluded if none of the secondary diagnosis fields contain 490-492 or 496.

 

New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems differ in how they classify adult asthma, data are not comparable before and after 2015. Data from 2015 are not shown because they contain a combination of ICD-9 and ICD-10 principal diagnosis codes.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Cases with 493.2 are excluded if none of the secondary diagnosis fields contain 490-492 or 496.

 

New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems differ in how they classify adult asthma, data are not comparable before and after 2015. Data from 2015 are not shown because they contain a combination of ICD-9 and ICD-10 principal diagnosis codes.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

IndicatorDescription:
People who are threatened with eviction, even before they lose their home, are more likely to report poor health, high blood pressure, depression, anxiety, and psychological distress. Eviction often leads to residential instability, moving into poor quality housing, overcrowding, and homelessness, all of which is associated with negative health among adults and children.

(From "The Hidden Health Crisis of Eviction" by Allison Bovell-Ammo and Megan Sandel)

Measures.how_calculated:
Count of executed evictions ordered by the New York City Housing Court, including those pending and scheduled as of December 31.

Eviction data are reported by New York City Marshals and gathered from NYC Open Data. For more information, see: https://data.cityofnewyork.us/City-Government/Evictions/6z8x-wfk4
Measures.Sources: New York City Department of Investigation

Measures.how_calculated:
Rate of executed evictions ordered by the New York City Housing Court, including those pending and scheduled as of December 31, per 10,000 housing units.

Eviction data are reported by New York City Marshals and gathered from NYC Open Data. For more information, see: https://data.cityofnewyork.us/City-Government/Evictions/6z8x-wfk4
Measures.Sources: New York City Department of Investigation

IndicatorName: NYC Agency Use of "Best Practice" Products
IndicatorDescription: NYC enacted a local law in 2005 that requires city agencies to reduce use of toxic products to control pests, and to adopt “Best Practices” instead. Best practice products use active ingredients with very low toxicity or involve formulation or application methods that minimize potential exposure and environmental spread.

Measures.how_calculated: Total count of pesticide applications made by NYC agencies or their contractors that meet the following qualifications: classified as insect growth regulator, insecticide, miticide, or termiticide; having the term bait or gel in the product name, or containing active ingredients boric acid, disodium octaborate tetrahydrate, sodium tetraborate (pentahydrate), indoxacarb, silica gel, diatomaceous earth, (Z)-9-tricosene, S-methoprene, spinosad, hydramethylnon, pyriproxyfen, or fipronil; and not containing active ingredients of the chemical classes pyrethrins, pyrethroids, N-methyl carbamates or organophosphorous compounds.
Measures.Sources: Bureau of Environmental Surveillance and Policy (BESP) Combined Analytic Data Set; New York City Pesticide Use Reporting System (NYCPURS)

Measures.how_calculated: Sum of pounds of solid pesticide applications made by NYC agencies or their contractors that meet the following qualifications: classified as insect growth regulator, insecticide, miticide, or termiticide; having the term bait or gel in the product name, or containing active ingredients boric acid, disodium octaborate tetrahydrate, sodium tetraborate (pentahydrate), indoxacarb, silica gel, diatomaceous earth, (Z)-9-tricosene, S-methoprene, spinosad, hydramethylnon, pyriproxyfen, or fipronil; and not containing active ingredients of the chemical classes pyrethrins, pyrethroids, N-methyl carbamates or organophosphorous compounds.
Measures.Sources: Bureau of Environmental Surveillance and Policy (BESP) Combined Analytic Data Set; New York City Pesticide Use Reporting System (NYCPURS)

IndicatorName: NYC Agency Use of Mosquito Control

Measures.how_calculated: Total count of pesticides applied by the Department of Health & Mental Hygiene's Vector Control program to control adult mosquitos that have tested positive for mosquito-borne illnesses such as West Nile Virus or Zika Virus. This includes the use of approved Ultra-low Volume pyrethroid insecticides Anvil 10+10 (EPA registration # 1021-1688-8329) or Duet Dual-Action Adulticide (EPA registration # 1021-1795-8329).
Measures.Sources: Bureau of Environmental Surveillance and Policy (BESP) Combined Analytic Data Set; New York City Pesticide Use Reporting System (NYCPURS)

Measures.how_calculated: Sum of pounds of solid pesticides applied by the Department of Health & Mental Hygiene's Vector Control program to control adult mosquitos that have tested positive for mosquito-borne illnesses such as West Nile Virus or Zika Virus. This includes the use of approved Ultra-low Volume pyrethroid insecticides Anvil 10+10 (EPA registration # 1021-1688-8329) or Duet Dual-Action Adulticide (EPA registration # 1021-1795-8329).
Measures.Sources: Bureau of Environmental Surveillance and Policy (BESP) Combined Analytic Data Set; New York City Pesticide Use Reporting System (NYCPURS)

Measures.how_calculated: Total count of pesticides applied by NYC agencies and their contractors to control mosquito larvae. Products contain a granular formulation of various strains of Bacillus thuringiensis and/or Bacillus sphaericus.
Measures.Sources: Bureau of Environmental Surveillance and Policy (BESP) Combined Analytic Data Set; New York City Pesticide Use Reporting System (NYCPURS)

IndicatorDescription: Violence is frequently described through homicide statistics. While it is a leading cause of death and captures the most severe form of violence, non-fatal violence-related injuries resulting in hospitalizations are much more common and help paint the larger picture on the burden of violence and its impact on the health and future of individuals, families, and communities.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of NYC non-fatal assault hospitalizations among all ages was identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: X92-X99, Y00-Y04, Y07-Y09, T(36-65).x3, T(36-65).xx3, T71.xx3, T74, T76. Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. Assaults classified as terrorism, legal intervention, or operations of war are excluded. All figures include NYC residents only.
Measures.Sources: Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System

Measures.how_calculated: Counts were calculated as described above and summed within five age groups (0-17, 18-24, 25-44, 45-64, 65+) and divided by the population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates, expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.
Measures.Sources: Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System

Measures.how_calculated: Number of deaths during cold season months of October-April with an underlying or contributing cause that includes excessive natural cold (ICD10 code X31) and hypothermia (ICD10 code T68), among NYC residents. Number excludes deaths due to excessive cold of man-made origin (ICD10 code W93) and intentional deaths (ICD10 codes X6-X9, Y0, Y35, Y36).
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

IndicatorName: Households reporting someone who uses electric medical equipment

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households reporting someone using electric medical equipment, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households reporting someone using electric medical equipment; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

IndicatorName: Asthma Emergency Department Visits (Children 0 to 4 Yrs Old) by NTA

Measures.how_calculated:
Average annual number of asthma-related emergency department (ED) visits among NYC resident children up to 4 years old, divided by the population of children up to 4 years old, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents. 

 

An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Measures.how_calculated:
Aggregated number of asthma-related emergency department (ED) visits among NYC resident children up to 4 years old. 

 

An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

IndicatorName: Asthma Emergency Department Visits (Children 5 to 17 Yrs Old)
IndicatorDescription: Severe asthma attacks can result in a visit to the ED. Certain exposures can trigger asthma symptoms, including smoke, air pollution, dust mites, cockroaches, mold, pollen and pet dander, among others.

Measures.how_calculated:
Number of asthma-related emergency department (ED) visits among NYC resident children aged 5 to 17 years.

 

ED visits include both patients who are treated and released in the ED (outpatients) and who are admitted as inpatients through the emergency department.

 

An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Measures.how_calculated:
Number of asthma-related emergency department (ED) visits among NYC resident children aged 5 to 17 years, divided by the population of children 5 to 17 years old, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents.

 

ED visits include both patients who are treated and released in the ED (outpatients) and who are admitted as inpatients through the emergency department.

 

An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

IndicatorDescription: Severe asthma attacks can result in a visit to the ED. Certain exposures can trigger asthma symptoms, including smoke, air pollution, dust mites, cockroaches, mold, pollen and pet dander, among others.

Measures.how_calculated:
Number of asthma-related emergency department (ED) visits among NYC adults (18 years and older). 

 

ED visits include both patients who are treated and released in the ED (outpatients) and who are admitted as inpatients through the emergency department.

 

An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015.  Because the ICD systems differ in how they classify adult asthma, data are not comparable before and after 2015. Data from 2015 are not shown for adults, because they contain a combination of ICD-9 and ICD-10 principal diagnosis codes.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Measures.how_calculated:
Number of asthma-related emergency department (ED) visits among NYC adults (18 years and older), divided by the population of adults (18 years and older) using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents.

 

ED visits include both patients who are treated and released in the ED (outpatients) and who are admitted as inpatients through the emergency department.

 

An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015.  Because the ICD systems differ in how they classify adult asthma, data are not comparable before and after 2015. Data from 2015 are not shown for adults, because they contain a combination of ICD-9 and ICD-10 principal diagnosis codes.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Measures.how_calculated:
Number of asthma-related emergency department (ED) visits among NYC adults (18 years and older), divided by the population in 5 year age groups, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents.

 

ED visits include both patients who are treated and released in the ED (outpatients) and who are admitted as inpatients through the emergency department.

 

 An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems differ in how they classify adult asthma, data are not comparable before and after 2015. Data from 2015 are not shown for adults, because they contain a combination of ICD-9 and ICD-10 principal diagnosis codes.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015.  Because the ICD systems differ in how they classify adult asthma, data are not comparable before and after 2015. Data from 2015 are not shown because they contain a combination of ICD-9 and ICD-10 principal diagnosis codes.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Measures.how_calculated:
Average annual number of asthma-related emergency department (ED) visits among NYC adults (18 years and older). Measures are provided down to the neighborhood tabulation area (NTA) level.

 

ED visits include both patients who are treated and released in the ED (outpatients) and who are admitted as inpatients through the emergency department.

 

An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015.  Because the ICD systems differ in how they classify adult asthma, data are not comparable before and after 2015. Data from 2015 are not shown because they contain a combination of ICD-9 and ICD-10 principal diagnosis codes.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

IndicatorName: Asthma Hospitalizations (Children 5 to 17 Yrs Old) by NTA

Measures.how_calculated:
Average annual number of asthma-related hospitalizations among NYC resident children aged 5 to 17 years, divided by the population of children 5 to 17 years old, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents. Measures are provided down to the neighborhood tabulation area (NTA) level.

 

 A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Average annual number of asthma-related hospitalizations among NYC resident children aged 5 to 17 years. Measures are provided down to the neighborhood tabulation area (NTA) level.

Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Measures.how_calculated:

Measures are provided down to the neighborhood tabulation area (NTA) level.

 

An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015.  Because the ICD systems differ in how they classify adult asthma, data are not comparable before and after 2015. Data from 2015 are not shown because they contain a combination of ICD-9 and ICD-10 principal diagnosis codes.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Measures.how_calculated:
Average annual number of asthma-related hospitalizations among NYC resident adults (18 years and older), divided by the population in 5 year age groups, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents. Measures are provided down to the neighborhood tabulation area (NTA) level. 

 

An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015.  Because the ICD systems differ in how they classify adult asthma, data are not comparable before and after 2015. Data from 2015 are not shown because they contain a combination of ICD-9 and ICD-10 principal diagnosis codes.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data
