IndicatorDescription: Walking distance to a park is defined as 1/4-mile or less to entrances of smaller sites, such as sitting areas and playgrounds, and 1/2-mile or less to entrances of larger parks. Parks and open space that are not under the NYC Parks Department jurisdiction are also included.

Measures.how_calculated: A map of "walk-to-a-park service areas" from the NYC Parks Department was overlayed onto a map of 2017 population estimates by census tract to calculate the percentage of the population that potentially live within the service area. These percentages were aggregated up to a neighborhood level.
Measures.Sources: New York City Department of Parks and Recreation; New York City DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau inter-censal population estimates

Measures.how_calculated:
The number of bodegas per supermarket within an area based on address of business.

Bodegas are defined as food purchasing establishments with less than 4,000 square foot and excludes specialty stores, such as bakeries and vitamin stores.

Supermarkets are defined as retail food purchasing establishments with greater than or equal to 10,000 square feet or have a chain supermarket name regardless of size.
Measures.Sources: NYS Department of Agriculture and Markets

IndicatorDescription: The percent of streets with bike lanes can affect cyclist and pedestrian safety, physical activity, and sustainable transportation use.

Measures.MeasurementType: Percent of Streets with Bicycle Lanes
Measures.how_calculated: Percentage of streets with bicycle lanes (conventional and protected bicycle lanes, excluding sharrows, dirt trails, boardwalks, and velodrome tracks).
Measures.Sources: New York City Department of Transportation

IndicatorName: Walking Distance to a Subway Station
IndicatorDescription: Percentage of population within a quarter-mile of a subway station entrance.

Measures.how_calculated: Walking distance to a subway station is defined as 1/4-mile or less. Distance was measured between the centroid of 2010 Census blocks and the nearest station entrance. Census block populations within areas defined as walking distance were summed across the neighborhood and divided by total neighborhood population.
Measures.Sources: Metropolitan Transportation Authority ; United States Census

IndicatorName: Children ever diagnosed with asthma (ages 0-13 years)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children ages 0-13 years who were ever diagnosed with asthma, divided by all children of the same ages, expressed as a percent.
Measures.Sources: NYC KIDS Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children ages 0-13 years who were ever diagnosed with asthma.
Measures.Sources: NYC KIDS Survey

IndicatorName: Children living in homes with cockroaches (ages 0-13 years)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children ages 0-13 years living in a home reporting cockroaches in the past 30 days, divided by the number of children in the area; expressed as a percent.
Measures.Sources: NYC KIDS Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children ages 0-13 years living in a home reporting cockroaches in the past 30 days
Measures.Sources: NYC KIDS Survey

IndicatorName: Children living in homes with mice (ages 0-13  years)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children ages 0-13 years living in a home with signs of mice in the past 90 days.
Measures.Sources: NYC KIDS Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children ages 0-13 years living in a home with signs of mice in the past 90 days, divided by the number of children in the area; expressed as a percent.
Measures.Sources: NYC KIDS Survey

IndicatorName: Children living in homes with cracks or holes (ages 0-13 years)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children ages 0-13 years living in homes with cracks or holes in the walls, ceiling or floors.
Measures.Sources: NYC KIDS Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children ages 0-13 years living in homes with cracks or holes in the walls, ceiling or floors, divided by the number of children in the area; expressed as a percent.
Measures.Sources: NYC KIDS Survey

IndicatorName: Children living in homes using supplemental heat (ages 0-13 years)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children ages 0-13 years living in a home that used supplemental heat during the winter.
Measures.Sources: NYC KIDS Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children ages 0-13 years living in a home that used supplemental heat during the winter, divided by the number of children in the area; expressed as a percent.
Measures.Sources: NYC KIDS Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Number of deaths with an underlying or contributing cause that includes the toxic effect of carbon monoxide (ICD10 code T58) and accidental injury/poisoning due to fire and flames (ICD10 codes X00-X09) among NYC residents. Excludes intentional deaths (ICD10 codes X60-Y09, Y35-36).
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated: Number of deaths with an underlying or contributing cause that includes the toxic effect of carbon monoxide (ICD10 code T58) and unintentional non-fire poisoning (ICD10 code X47) among NYC residents. Excludes intentional deaths (ICD10 codes X60-Y09, Y35-36).
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated: Number of deaths with an underlying or contributing cause that includes the toxic effect of carbon monoxide (ICD10 code T58) among NYC residents that are neither fire-related or non-fire-related, or have codes indicating both fire- and non-fire related causes. Excludes intentional deaths (ICD10 codes X60-Y09, Y35-36).
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

IndicatorName: Renter-occupied homes with any health-related maintenance problems
IndicatorDescription: Housing without health-threatening maintenance deficiencies is an important environmental component of health.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of renter-occupied households reporting any health-related maintenance problems (cockroaches, mice or rats in the building, cracks or holes in walls, ceilings or floors, leaks from outside, toilet breakdowns, lack of air conditioning, heating equipment breakdown, additional heating required, or broken plaster or peeling paint larger than 8½ x 11 inches).
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of renter-occupied households reporting any health-related maintenance problems (cockroaches, mice or rats in the building, cracks or holes in walls, ceilings or floors, leaks from outside, toilet breakdowns, lack of air conditioning, heating equipment breakdown, additional heating required, or broken plaster or peeling paint larger than 8½ x 11 inches),divided by the number of renter-occupied households in the area; expressed as percent..
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

IndicatorDescription: Violence is frequently described through homicide statistics. While it is a leading cause of death and captures the most severe form of violence, non-fatal violence-related injuries resulting in emergency department visits are much more common and help paint the larger picture on the burden of violence and its impact on the health and future of individuals, families, and communities.

Measures.how_calculated: Counts were calculated as described above and summed within five age groups (0-17, 18-24, 25-44, 45-64, 65+) and divided by the population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.
Measures.Sources: Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System

Measures.how_calculated: Number of NYC nonfatal assault emergency department visits among all ages was identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: X92-X99, Y00-Y04, Y07-Y09, T(36-65).x3, T(36-65).xx3, T71.xx3, T74, T76. Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. Assaults classified as terrorism, legal intervention, or operations of war are excluded. All figures include NYC residents only.
Measures.Sources: Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System

IndicatorName: Households that postponed health care in the last 12 months

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households that postponed health care for financial reasons, rounded to the nearest 1,000. Health care includes dental, preventive care or check-up, mental health, treatment or diagnosis of illness or health condition, and prescription drugs; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

IndicatorName: Homes with reported falls among adults 65 and older

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households that reported anyone 65 or older having fallen in the home.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households that reported anyone 65 or older having fallen in the home, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

IndicatorDescription: Carbon monoxide exposure can be life-threatening or fatal. Maintaining surveillance of ED visits and hospitalizations allows us to understand the burden of CO-related health impacts in NYC and identify trends over time.

Measures.how_calculated:
The number of NYC residents treated in an emergency department (ED), including those admitted as inpatients after being seen in an ED. Prior to October 1, 2015*, includes those with an ICD-9-CM diagnosis code of 986 for carbon monoxide poisoning and any unintentional fire-related injury code within the range of E890.0-E899.9. After October 1, 2015, includes those with an ICD-10-CM diagnosis code of T58 for accidental or undetermined-cause carbon monoxide poisoning and any fire-related code within the range of X00-X08. For all years, excludes records with intentional injury codes.

 

*Since October 1, 2015, all causes of emergency department (ED) visit and hospitalization are classified according to the ICD-10-CM classification system. Data from years prior to 2015 are not directly comparable to those after. Also, data from 2015 prior to the transition are not directly comparable to data from 2015 after the transition due to differing case definitions.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

IndicatorName: Home fall-related emergency department visits among older adults

Measures.how_calculated: Age-adjusted rates were calculated per 100,000 population 65 years and older weighted to the 2016 NYC DOHMH population estimates using the following age groups for weighting: 65-74, 75-84, and 85+ years old. Numerator consists of NYC ED visits related to falls among adults aged 65 years and older, identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: V00.1(1-5,8)1; V00.2(1,2,8)1; V00.3(1,2,8)1; V00.8(1-3,9)1; W00.0-W15; W16.0(1-3)2; W16.1(1-3)2; W16.3(1-3)2; W16.42x; W16.5(1-3)2; W16.6(1,2,7)2; W16.7(1,2)2; W16.8(1-3)2; W16.92x, W17; W18.1(1,2)x; W18.2xx; W18.3(0,1,9)x; W19. ED visits for a fall that occurred at home were identified using place of injury ICD10 code Y920 and then limited to the following building classes: "Condominiums," "Elevator Apartments," "One-family Dwellings," "Two-family Dwellings," "Walk-up Apartments," "Residence Multiple Use." Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. All figures include NYC residents only.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) emergency department data, 2016, updated January 2018. ; NYC DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau interpolated intercensal population estimates, 2016. Updated September 2017.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of NYC ED visitis related to falls among adults aged 65 years and older was identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: V00.1(1-5,8)1; V00.2(1,2,8)1; V00.3(1,2,8)1; V00.8(1-3,9)1; W00.0-W15; W16.0(1-3)2; W16.1(1-3)2; W16.3(1-3)2; W16.42x; W16.5(1-3)2; W16.6(1,2,7)2; W16.7(1,2)2; W16.8(1-3)2; W16.92x, W17; W18.1(1,2)x; W18.2xx; W18.3(0,1,9)x; W19. ED visits for a fall that occurred at home were identified using place of injury ICD10 code Y920 and then limited to the following building classes: "Condominiums," "Elevator Apartments," "One-family Dwellings," "Two-family Dwellings," "Walk-up Apartments," "Residence Multiple Use." Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. All figures include NYC residents only.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) emergency department data, 2016, updated January 2018.

IndicatorName: Home fall-related hospitalizations among older adults

Measures.how_calculated: Age-adjusted rates were calculated per 100,000 population 65 years and older weighted to the 2016 NYC DOHMH population estimates using the following age groups for weighting: 65-74, 75-84, and 85+ years old. Numerator consists of NYC hospitalizations related to falls among adults aged 65 years and older, identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: V00.1(1-5,8)1; V00.2(1,2,8)1; V00.3(1,2,8)1; V00.8(1-3,9)1; W00.0-W15; W16.0(1-3)2; W16.1(1-3)2; W16.3(1-3)2; W16.42x; W16.5(1-3)2; W16.6(1,2,7)2; W16.7(1,2)2; W16.8(1-3)2; W16.92x, W17; W18.1(1,2)x; W18.2xx; W18.3(0,1,9)x; W19. Hospitalizations for a fall that occurred at home were identified using place of injury ICD10 code Y920 and then limited to the following building classes: "Condominiums," "Elevator Apartments," "One-family Dwellings," "Two-family Dwellings," "Walk-up Apartments," "Residence Multiple Use." Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. All figures include NYC residents only.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) emergency department data, 2016, updated January 2018. ; NYC DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau interpolated intercensal population estimates, 2016. Updated September 2017.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of NYC hospitalizations related to falls among adults aged 65 years and older was identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: V00.1(1-5,8)1; V00.2(1,2,8)1; V00.3(1,2,8)1; V00.8(1-3,9)1; W00.0-W15; W16.0(1-3)2; W16.1(1-3)2; W16.3(1-3)2; W16.42x; W16.5(1-3)2; W16.6(1,2,7)2; W16.7(1,2)2; W16.8(1-3)2; W16.92x, W17; W18.1(1,2)x; W18.2xx; W18.3(0,1,9)x; W19. Hospitalizations for a fall that occurred at home were identified using place of injury ICD10 code Y920 and then limited to the following building classes: "Condominiums," "Elevator Apartments," "One-family Dwellings," "Two-family Dwellings," "Walk-up Apartments," "Residence Multiple Use." Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. All figures include NYC residents only.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) emergency department data, 2016, updated January 2018.

IndicatorDescription: 5-Year Heat Stress Hospitalizations

Measures.how_calculated:
The number of NYC residents admitted to a NYC hospital during the months of May-September summed over a 5-year period for the effects of heat and light due to weather conditions or undetermined cause. Residents with a diagnosis of excessive heat due to non-environmental conditions were excluded. Data are based on date of admission and include those who were admitted with a diagnosis of heat-related illness, even if that was not the principal diagnosis. The data also include patients admitted to the hospital after being treated in an emergency department. 

 

Numbers are summed by 5-year age groups and divided by the 5-year summed population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates, to produce average annualized rates. Quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. The average annual age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.

 

Notes: The coding system used to represent diagnoses changed in October 2015. Cases admitted before October 1, 2015 are represented by International Classification of Diseases (ICD), 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) codes 992.0-992.9, E900.0 or E900.9. Cases admitted on or after October 1, 2015, are represented by the ICD, 10th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) codes T67, X30, X32.  Cases with diagnoses represented by ICD-9-CM code E900.1 (if admitted before October 1, 2015) or ICD-10-CM code W92 (if admitted on or after October 1, 2015) were excluded. Because of the October 1, 2015 change in diagnostic codes from ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM, changes in numbers and rates over time should be interpreted with caution because they may be in part due to changes in the coding system.
Measures.Sources: New York City DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau inter-censal population estimates; Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System

The number of NYC residents admitted to a NYC hospital during the months of May-September summed over a 5-year period for the effects of heat and light due to weather conditions or undetermined cause. Because of the October 1, 2015 change in diagnostic codes from ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM, changes in numbers and rates over time should be interpreted with caution because they may be in part due to changes in the coding system.
Measures.Sources: New York City DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau inter-censal population estimates; Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System

IndicatorDescription: The New York City (NYC) Heat Vulnerability Index (HVI) is a measure of how the risk of heat-related illness or death differs across neighborhoods. Neighborhood risk factors that increase heat- vulnerability in NYC are: less home air conditioning, less green space, hotter surface temperatures, and more residents who are low-income or non-Latinx Black. Differences in these risk factors across neighborhoods are rooted in past and present racism.

Measures.how_calculated:
Each neighborhood receives a score from 1 (lowest risk) to 5 (highest risk) based on a statistical model that uses social and environmental factors to estimate risk of heat-related death across NYC neighborhoods. A low vulnerability score does not mean no risk. Every neighborhood has residents at risk for heat illness and death. Residents who are at highest heat risk are those who do not have or use air conditioning AND are older or have chronic health conditions or serious mental illnesses.

 

To learn more about the HVI calculations, visit the HVI FAQ.

 

Visit www.nyc.gov/health/heat for more information about heat illness and how to prevent it. NYS has its own HVI information.
Measures.Sources: American Community Survey (2013-2017 5-yr estimates); New York City Department of Parks and Recreation (2017); U. S. Geological Survey LandSat (2018); United States Census Housing and Vacancy Survey (2017)
